SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, yesterday, 14 March, was Commonwealth Day. It has a particular significance for Australia in 1988, when Commonwealth nations are making such a significant contribution to our bicentennial celebrations. The quarter of the world's population comprising the Commonwealth is spread amongst small countries and large, developed and developing, from all continents and both hemispheres.

SPEECH.PARA: Within the framework provided by the Commonwealth, people from the widest range of cultures, races and religions imaginable meet on an equal footing, share their views and their friendship, and co-operate on matters of mutual concern. This is what makes the Commonwealth a valuable and constructive international institution.

The Vancouver meeting of Commonwealth Heads of Government, which took place in October last year, provided an excellent example of such productive cooperation. Commonwealth leaders agreed on a shared approach on issues ranging from world trade to disarmament. Constructive initiatives were taken in many of these areas.

The outstanding political issue continuing to confront the Commonwealth remains, of course, the situation in southern Africa. The recent deterioration there, caused by the further repressive measures introduced by the South African Government, only underlines the continuing tragedy and the need for every effort to be made to bring about peaceful changes. Whether the Commonwealth's longstanding ambition to see a peaceful end to apartheid will be achieved will, of course, depend on many factors beyond our immediate control. I have no doubt, however, that when the histories come to be written, the Commonwealth's role in providing an international lead in the struggle against apartheid will be acknowledged and commended.

Madam Speaker, Commonwealth Day provides a sobering reminder of the tragic denial of basic human rights to the majority in South Africa. I should like to assure the House that, under this Government, Australia will continue to be at the forefront of Commonwealth efforts to promote peaceful change in South Africa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition joins the Government in this brief moment to mark the significance and importance of the Commonwealth. Many of the things that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his statement are things with which the Opposition readily identifies itself. I certainly welcome the fact that the present Leader of the Australian Labor Party has a markedly more positive attitude towards the Commonwealth than did his predecessor the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), who, in 1981, described it as `an extravagant indulgence of little relevance to international affairs or Australia's role in the world'. Therefore, I certainly welcome the changed attitude of the Government. I also, of course, note the Prime Minister's remarks about the importance of bringing apartheid to an end as a Commonwealth goal. The Opposition associates itself with that goal. I note that, consistent with the Government's failure to give adequate emphasis in its foreign affairs perspective to the region immediately adjoining Australia, of course, there is no reference in the statement to the turbulent events in Fiji and other matters that have impacted upon regional members of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I share the aspiration of the Prime Minister, as does everybody on our side of the House, that efforts to bring an end to the repressive conditions in South Africa are successful. I say in passing that we would be less than consistent and we would expose ourselves to a charge of hypocrisy if we did not also acknowledge that there exists within many Commonwealth countries basic denials of human rights and a basic denial of the principles of a free Press, and parliamentary and liberal democracy, which are at the heart and at the core of many of the ideals around which the modern Commonwealth was founded.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether the Government has done anything for sole parents, who are among the poorest families in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that there would be broad agreement that sole parents require three broad areas of assistance. Firstly, they require adequate income to support themselves and their children when they do not have work. Secondly, they require services to enable them to work, as most sole parents are of an age at which most members of the community are at the peak of their working lives. Thirdly, assistance is required for those sole parents who have not been employed for a long period to get the confidence and skills to obtain employment. The record of this Government in all of these three areas is a proud record. We have increased payments for children from $10 to $22 a week, and to $28 a week for older children. We have increased the mother's and guardian's allowance from $6 a week to $12 a week, a 100 per cent increase, and extended it to all sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries. The poverty trap changes of last year were of major assistance to sole parents. The amount that they can earn each week before they start losing pension was significantly raised. The amount a sole parent with three children could earn increased from $48 a week to $76 a week, a 58 per cent increase. The earnings credit introduced in the last Budget means that sole parents who are just starting work or who do casual work get to keep much more of their pension.

ANSWER.PARA: We have dramatically expanded the availability of child care places and have targeted those places so that sole parents are major users of the child care program. We have made sole parents a priority group for the Commonwealth Employment Service and for labour market programs. Sole parents are becoming major users of the range of labour market transition programs.

This activity is showing very significant results. An analysis of recently released Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, carried out by the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research, shows that the income position of female sole parents improved between 1982 and 1986 and the percentage in poverty declined. Part of the improvement comes from the higher real incomes of female sole parents who are not employed, that is, from real increases in pensions and allowances. Further improvement comes from the increased number of sole parents in the labour force. While the total number of female sole parents rose by 4.6 per cent in four years, the number in the labour force increased by 23.3. per cent. When one compares the Government's approach and results with the Opposition's position, the difference is stark. The Opposition would decimate labour market programs, destroy the child care program, shed its public housing responsibilities, and cancel the pension of every sole parent whose youngest child is over ten.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of rot.

—It is not. The fact is that only a few months ago the Opposition committed itself to reducing the qualifying age for sole parent pensions to 10 years for the youngest child. This Government is about helping sole parents to live a decent life and to participate in the mainstream of community activity. The Opposition is on about taking away their pensions, leaving them on their own, without pensions, without access to child care, without secure housing and without the chance to get back into a job after years of looking after children. The Government, notwithstanding a record which compares very favourably with the record of any previous government, is committed to do more for sole parents. Tomorrow I will introduce the final piece of legislation to establish the child support scheme. The Government will be considering the Cass review recommendations regarding sole parents in the next few months. Under this Government sole parents have had a chance to live a decent life as part of the community. Under the conservatives here and those in the States, the future for sole parents would be very bleak.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

I ask a simple question as the basis for them going on to make some observations. I ask the question, rhetorically: Where was the outcry from the Opposition when a computer print-out containing confidential information revealing the names of hundreds of patients with bad debts was found in a Canberra pre-school? Where was the outcry then? The computer print-outs clearly revealed patients names, how much they owed and the state of their indebtedness, but there was not a word then from these great protectors of the rights of privacy opposite.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Medical Association (AMA) responded. The Australian Capital Territory AMA President, Dr David McNicol, dismissed it as `a political stunt'. Another AMA spokesman, Dr Brian Richards, was reported on Capital 7 news on 26 February as saying that he believes `patients accounts are in the public domain and that their confidentiality has not been breached'. Dr McNicol went on to say that he had asked the principals of the practice to call the Australian Federal Police to investigate. The Federal Police have confirmed that there has been no request at any formal level for such an inquiry.

I call on the Opposition to drop its double standards on this issue and to join with us in calling on the AMA to have the police investigate what appears to be a serious breach of patient confidentiality. I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to inform us whether, if that police inquiry into patient confidentiality does not result in prosecutions, he intends to take personal legal action against the doctors in charge of the practice and to pay for it himself. He should either say that he will or he should admit to the hypocrisy of his position and to the fact that he might support a minority of doctors who overcharge, but he does not support the rights of patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Treasurer to inform the House of the Government's reaction to today's balance of payments figure relating to the month of February.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reaction of the Government to today's release of the February balance of payments figure is a favourable one. The figure, at $737m, not only sits comfortably with the Budget time forecast for the current account at $11.5 billion, but confirms that last month's very low number of $457m was not revised up, which stands to the tally of the current account. This means that the current account forecast in the Government's Budget last year-that is, the current account for the 12 months to June of this year at $11.5 billion-should now be easily met, and, if anything, exceeded. In the eight months to date the current account is $2 billion in front of the same period last year. It now stands at $7.5 billion. So even if we were to get the same monthly numbers for the balance of this year as we had last year, the $2 billion is now secure and, therefore, the current account will drop from $13.4 billion last year to about $11.4 billion or $11.5 billion this year.

ANSWER.PARA: Given the pattern of the monthly numbers, the likelihood is that we could improve upon each monthly figure that exists for March to June of 1987 in March to June of 1988. If we get an improvement in those figures, there is every possibility that the current account deficit will come in at a figure less than $11.5 billion, less than the Budget forecast.

In disaggregating some of the data in relation to exports and imports in this release today by the Statistician, we find that exports were doing well. In the three months to February, exports were 21 per cent higher than they were for the corresponding period a year earlier. On a trend basis, we have seen a trade surplus in the accounts for the last four months.

Imports have risen from the low January figure, but almost half of the endogenous or underlying level of imports, at $469m, was $190m of plant and machinery imports; most of it was brought in as machinery importation. So almost half of the endogenous import growth is from plant and equipment, and it is that importation of plant and equipment which is underpinning our current account volume change-the growth in net exports-which is changing the Australian current account and adding more capacity to our import competing and exporting industries.

This change in the importation of plant and equipment squares with the investment data which we have received in recent months. The latest data, which is after the collapse in world stock markets, shows that, for actual investment in plant and equipment for the December quarter, the figures are up by 10 percentage points; and the expectations in the Statistician's expectation survey for 1988-89 show a real growth in plant and equipment of about 10 percentage points, that is a 10 percentage points real increase in plant and equipment investment.

If we look at the balances of the figuring in the current account released by the Statistician today, we find that the current account is not just at forecast but ahead of forecast; that the likelihood is that it will come in under the Budget forecast; that we continue to replace and change volumes in the current account; that we are continuing to run a trade surplus; and that we are continuing to see a strong level of plant and equipment imports, which is going to enhance our capacity to import, replace and to export, and that is squaring with the very strong investment numbers which we are seeing come through for plant and equipment after the crash on stock markets and which are being confirmed in the expectations data by business taken by the Statistician in relation to 1988-89.

TALK.START.PARA: —An excellent result.

—All in all, as my colleague said by interjection, an excellent result, and one that confirms the trend. But it still indicates that we have a long way to go and that the restraint and the discipline of Australia will need to be maintained. But the nation is being rewarded handsomely in this very large shift in the current account deficit and the continuing change which we are seeing is promoting so much more confidence in our foreign exchange and interest rates markets.

—When did the Prime Minister first learn that his former Minister, Mr Young, had been employed by Qantas Airways Ltd, and from whom? Will the Prime Minister also advise the House whether over the past three weeks he has personally contacted Australian companies trying to find a job, or to facilitate the finding of a job, for this former Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer directly the questions put to me by the honourable member for Deakin but, before I do so, it is obviously necessary that I should again, as is so often necessary, expose the hypocrisy of the Opposition. the question of Mr Young's possible employment by Qantas was related to the question of his tenure of the presidency of the Australian Labor Party. It is interesting and pertinent to recall what happened when the Opposition was in government. The Leader of the Opposition has attempted to suggest that nothing would be further from the Opposition's mind than that it would have a President of the Liberal Party concurrently holding any office under the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us get it quite clear in regard to the President of the Liberal Party from 1982 to July 1985, the Hon. Alexander James Forbes. The Hon. Alexander James Forbes, more affectionately known as Jim, held appointments with government authorities. The Fraser Government put him on the Council of the National Library in 1979, appointing him Chairman in 1982. He held that position until 1985. The Fraser Government appointed him Chairman of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories Commission in 1978, a position he held until 1984, concurrently with his presidency of the Liberal Party. The combined effect of these appointments was that over the two years when he was President of the Party, which in coalition was in government, Dr Forbes held two remunerated positions under the Crown. There was no problem then as far as the conservatives were concerned of jobs for the boys.

Let me make it quite clear in saying that that I am not in any way suggesting that there was anything improper about those appointments. Indeed, they continued for a period under my Government. I am concerned only to point out to the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member who asked the question the hypocrisy of the Opposition is stating that Liberal Party Presidents did not hold government sponsored office. As distinct from those positions, let me make it quite clear that the Qantas post in question is not even government sponsored, government initiated or government blessed. This makes any attack by the Leader of the Opposition that he has been carrying on in the media all the more bizarre. The decision was one entirely for Qantas to make, as for any of its other consultancy requirements. I make the point unequivocally to the honourable gentleman who asked the question that I had no part in the appointment in any shape or form.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you learn of it?

—I remember and understand the question. I was informed about the end of February by Mr Young that consultations had taken place between Qantas management and himself. I was told about them after they occurred. I had no part in initiating them. The first knowledge I had--
—Before the appointment?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting across the table.

—The position is quite clear. The first I knew of these consultations was when Mr Young, some time about the end of February, informed me of them. I had no part in the initiation of it and I subsequently had nothing to do with it.
—You could have stopped it.

—No, I did nothing to stop it because the simple fact is that Mr Young was no longer a member of this Parliament or a Minister of this Government. Mr Young as a private citizen was entitled in his post-parliamentary situation and career to seek remuneration and positions that were appropriate to his capacities and to his experience. Not only did I feel no compunction to stop it, I did not.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable gentleman asked me, secondly, whether I took any action to assist Mr Young to get some possible positions in the private sector. The answer is yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the case of a Queensland man, Ian Grey, who has been detained in Mozambique since 3 November 1987. Can the Minister inform the House of action taken by the Australian Government in relation to Mr Grey's welfare and to ensure that he is brought to trial? Can he further inform the House when it is expected that Mr Grey will be brought before the court?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought honourable members might have missed me without recognising that I had been away. I have not had as much publicity in recent times as I would like. Mr Ian Grey is an Australian citizen, a missionary, who was detained in Mozambique on 3 November 1987. Since his detention the Australian Government has made a number of representations on his behalf. The consular representative, Mr Alexander, from Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe, has gone to Maputo, the capital of Mozambique, on a number of occasions-and I think he is currently there-to look after Mr Grey's consular interests. When I was there I took the opportunity of making inquiries in Mr Grey's interests and in particular to see what processes were in place to have his trial brought forward. It was my understanding that there was an undertaking to bring the trial forward within a relatively short time. It has been asserted by the Mozambiquans that they only undertook to bring the papers in relation to Mr Grey's case before the court. That could easily have been so in that translation may have been a problem. Nonetheless, they have said the alleged offence is collaborating with armed bandits, which I presume is the Renamo forces. They claim they have evidence of these charges. We have urged that the charges be heard properly and in open court. It has been suggested that the media will probably be allowed to attend the trial which, as far as we are aware at this point, will be held before a military tribunal according to Mozambique law.

ANSWER.PARA: The offences themselves are quite serious and are subject to the death penalty or up to 30 years imprisonment. We have made representations on Mr Grey's behalf in relation to the form of legal representation he may have advocating for him before the court. Under Mozambiquan law it is our understanding that it will have to be a Mozambiquan lawyer. However we have sought to negotiate arrangements where-as it is the family's wish-an outside lawyer, that is from a country such as Australia, may be retained by the Grey family.

The last we heard was that the trial date was set for 15 March but that has now been deferred. All I can say is that we are making every effort we can to protect this man's interests. A great deal of effort has gone into it. We have diverted the energies of a very senior diplomat to work regularly and for extended periods in Maputo looking after his interests. When the trial gets under way we will second that man on a temporary basis to Maputo to cover the trial. That will mean that we will have to send additional back-up staff to support him and to complement the vacancy which is created in our representation in Harare. I stress we are not represented on the ground in Maputo and that adds to our problems. Finally, I should say that we have been in regular contact with the Grey family on this case.

—Will the Treasurer advise the House of the latest economic indices, particularly as they affect the most populous State, New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen in the December quarter national accounts, and since in partial indicators, indications of the strength of the economy, notwithstanding the decline in the stock market during October of last year. In February employment figures were released which show that employment has grown by 116,500 since October; that is, we have seen a phenomenal rate of growth of employment which has lowered our registered unemployment rate to 7.4 per cent. I might add that that employment figure now totals an aggregate 16 per cent employment growth since 1983; in five years, about 2 1/4 times the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average. In the December quarter the consumer price index was 1.7 per cent, down to 7.1 per cent over the year, and, therefore, on course for the Government's projected 6 per cent by the end of the financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: We now have inflation decelerating rapidly from the depreciation induced rise during the past 12 months. In the same time, we saw average weekly ordinary time earnings up by 1.2 per cent in the three months to November, to provide an increase in the average weekly ordinary time earnings rate of 5.3 per cent over the year. As I said a few minutes earlier, in plant and equipment investment we have seen a 10 percentage points increase in the December quarter. In housing approvals in the three months to January we saw a rise of 29 per cent over the same period the previous year. Of course, we have seen an improvement in the current account deficit.

All of those influences are even more manifest in the largest State, New South Wales. Employment growth in the year to February in New South Wales has run at an annual rate of 5.5 percentage points, which is twice the average of the rest of the country and about three times the OECD average. In New South Wales, private sector job vacancies have risen by 26 per cent since the December quarter of 1986, compared with a slight fall for the rest of Australia. The growth in overtime worked in New South Wales is five times that in the rest of Australia. The housing sector is booming; the construction sector is booming; manufacturing is buoyant. In New South Wales we see faster product growth than the average of all of the other States.

We hear debate in the nation about it being a time for change in New South Wales. One may ask: A time for a change from what? A change from 5.5 per cent employment growth to something less? A change from 26 per cent growth in private sector vacancies to something less? A change in overtime figures, which are five times the national average? A change from booming housing, construction and tourism sectors? A change from the more general provision of infrastructure and facilities that has been presided over by the New South Wales Labor Government?

The fact is that New South Wales is enjoying better prosperity and better conditions than any other State in the Commonwealth. That is being delivered by the Unsworth Labor Government with the support of the national Government through its economic strategy. In the Liberal Party's desperate attempts to secure election in New South Wales, it now seeks to rupture and puncture the whole climate of restraint engendered in the nation by the Commonwealth Government, by seeking to spend $1,400m of additional outlays in the budgetary year which, in the unhappy event of its election, would be the next budgetary year. That is the equivalent of $4,000m of Commonwealth spending, one bearing in mind that this Government went to an election with $400m of spending commitments.

This shocking extravagance on the part of the New South Wales Liberal leader is simply mirroring the extravagance and irresponsibility of the honourable member for Bennelong at the last national election. Interestingly, in this cloning that we have seen in New South Wales, Mr Greiner is putting down his Federal leader, saying:
We're explicitly not trying to do what John Howard did in terms of saying we're going to use all this to give you a lot of goodies.
In other words, Mr Greiner is calling his Federal leader irresponsible. Mr Greiner said:
No, I don't have the John Howard problem, I do not have a where's-the-money-coming-from problem, and I deliberately avoided trying to bribe the electorate.

That is what Mr Greiner says today. The other day he said, `The same people who did not believe Mr Howard's tax cuts'-and that included the whole Liberal Party and over half the nation-`in July will ask themselves whether they believe Mr Unsworth's far more irresponsible strategy'. The implication is that the tax cut policy in the last election of the honourable member for Bennelong was irresponsible and unbelievable. Mr Greiner goes on to say today that he does not have a John Howard problem-a pretty nice condemnation from the leader of the Liberal Party in the State of New South Wales, where Mr Howard lives and where he comes from.

It is not just the Federal President of the Liberal Party who is saying that the Liberal Party did not deserve to win the last national election and Senator Stone saying that the Liberal Party did not deserve to be trusted on tax and did not deserve to win the last election, but now Mr Greiner is saying that he is explicitly not trying to do what John Howard did and has said, `We do not have a John Howard problem'. Honourable members will remember that great apologia by the honourable member for Bennelong in the post-election analysis-how his demise was all Joh's fault. Now every senior person in the Liberal Party, from John Elliott down to Mr Greiner, is saying that the Liberals did not deserve to win the last election, that Mr Howard had made unbelievable and irresponsible commitments and bribes and that Mr Greiner does not have a John Howard problem.

Perhaps we are starting to see some real and reflective analysis of the last national election result. We on this side of the House understand that the public would not take on this tawdry, tattered group opposite who sought to derail the national strategy of restraint on consumption and a change in our current account balance, for $8 billion of unfunded tax cuts to be now followed up by an irresponsible leader in New South Wales with the equivalent of $4 billion of Commonwealth spending in a $1,400m bribe to take him to a New South Wales poll. That is what the issues are about. The only responsible party in this country at the moment is the Australian Labor Party, which, with a modest set of electoral commitments at the last election, produced a Budget surplus from the massive $10 billion Budget imbalance those opposite bequeathed to us. Now the New South Wales Labor Leader, Barrie Unsworth, is going to an election with a modest $260m platform of redistributing resources to low income families, to people who really need it.

The public is now getting a chance to make a judgment about where the decency and responsibility in Australian politics lies-and it does not lie on the conservative side of politics. The conservatives are now stabbing themselves in the back with denials about irresponsibility, their `where is the money coming from' problems, and their not having a John Howard complex. They are all remarks we will be running and rerunning until the honourable member for Bennelong understands that his goose is cooked in Australian public life. The conservatives cannot go around the world throwing away tax cuts while we have a current account imbalance of this size, and they cannot go into a national election with any confidence or have the world's financial markets treat them with any sensibility while ever they are led by an irresponsible person who has ruined the economy once and would try to ruin it a second time.

—Not surprisingly, my question is directed to the Minister for Community Services and Health and relates to the welfare of patients in New South Wales.
—Do you want some more names, George?

—Unlike the honourable member for O'Connor, I look after patients, not doctors. Can the Minister for Community Services and Health inform the House as to what impact a major expansion of private hospital beds in New South Wales would have on private health insurance contribution rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the House has returned to issues of substance in health policy. The question asked is, of course, central to health policy. The first part of my answer to the honourable member for Canning is that the effect of an expansion of private hospital beds in New South Wales would be a distinct rise in the private insurance rate in New South Wales, for the obvious reason that already between 30 and 40 per cent of beds in the private hospital system are not used. This high level of underutilisation is already keeping up private insurance rates. Simply adding to that number of underutilised beds in New South Wales would increase the burden of those who pay private insurance to cover this relatively low level of utilisation.

ANSWER.PARA: Commonsense quite clearly points out that more beds does not equate with better health care. It has no regard for efficiency, for proper planning or for the rational distribution of health services. As an article in the Sydney Morning Herald pointed out, it would also attract specialists further away from the public hospital system. DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask for leave of the House to move a motion authorising the publication of the paper relating to a possible contravention of the Health Insurance Act tabled by me earlier today.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.
Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from moving forthwith that this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the joint opinion prepared for the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons regarding the Commonwealth Minister for Health and the Health Insurance Act, dated 10 March 1988, tabled today by the Leader of the Opposition.

The reason that I seek a suspension of Standing Orders on this occasion is very simple. About three weeks ago the Opposition, after the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) had corrected an answer he had given earlier in the day, claimed that the Minister for Community Services and Health had been involved in a breach of the Health Insurance Act in that he had been involved in a course of conduct which had resulted in information being made available of a confidential kind relating to particular medical practitioners. The basis of the Opposition's argument on that occasion was that the Minister for Community Services and Health had been involved in a breach of the Health Insurance Act. That was the basis of the charge which had been made by the Opposition against the Minister for Community Services and Health.

On that occasion, amid a great deal of heat, fury and sound, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Community Services and Health both waxed lyrical about how they had handled the matter with great propriety. With a great flourish, the Prime Minister came into the Parliament and tabled an opinion which had been obtained hastily and, as it now turns out, on inadequate instructions to the Solicitor-General. With a great flourish the Prime Minister threw it down and said, `There you are, this completely clears the Minister for Health'. It was perfectly obvious on the day that opinion was tabled, as the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) know, that the opinion was obtained on a very narrowly drawn set of instructions. It was perfectly obvious that if the Solicitor-General had been more fully briefed, if he had been provided with the answers that had been furnished, the answers that were briefed, in relation to the opinion that I tabled earlier today, the Solicitor-General may well have reached a different conclusion.

But that was not the case. From that day on, the Minister for Health and other members of the Government front bench ran around the country saying, `The Opposition does not have a case against the Minister because the Solicitor-General has provided us with an opinion which says that he was completely in the clear'. But now, three weeks later, the Opposition has been given, as has the Prime Minister, copies of an opinion obtained by the Australian Society of Orthopaedic Surgeons which is directly at odds with the opinion that has been given by the Solicitor-General. I am not saying that the opinion provided by the surgeons is right and that the opinion--

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought you were.

—Hang on! Do not get too excited. I am not saying that the opinion provided by the Solicitor-General is wrong. What I am saying, and what I think this Parliament ought to be willing to accept, is that the opinion tabled by me today ought to be given the same currency and the same publication as the opinion tabled by the Prime Minister. It is as simple as that. If the Prime Minister and the Minister for Community Services and Health are not prepared to have the opinion published they can only be accused of engaging in a cover-up to protect the Minister for Community Services and Health. It is as simple as that. If the Minister for Community Services and Health is so absolutely certain of his position, there is a very simple procedure for the Prime Minister to adopt. That procedure is to do with the opinion I tabled today the very same thing that was done with the opinion tabled by the Prime Minister which he obtained from the Solicitor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: It is pretty obvious why he does not want to do that. The opinion I tabled today says in very clear terms that the Minister has been in breach of the Health Insurance Act. It says in very clear terms that the excuse and the argument of an honest mistake is not available. It says in very clear terms that the officer procedure referred to by the Minister when he gave answers in the House is also not an excuse. It says in very clear terms, and damningly for the Minister, that, even if the provider numbers had not been made available, the Minister was in breach of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act because under section 130 of the Health Insurance Act it is a breach of that Act for any material relating to any person to be made available. Even though the provider numbers may not have been provided, according to the opinion that I have tabled today the Minister was in breach of the Health Insurance Act.

Against that background and in those circumstances members of the Australian public are entitled to have the contents of that opinion made available to them. We have been given the opinion of the Solicitor-General, an opinion that was based on very narrow grounds. I want to know why this opinion cannot be treated in exactly the same way? Why cannot this opinion be the subject of this motion? The only reason is that the Government, and most particularly the Prime Minister and the Minister for Community Services and Health, want to engage in some cover-up of the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Prime Minister should do one very simple thing: he should get hold of the opinion that I tabled today and he should get hold of the opinion that was tabled by the Solicitor-General. He ought to send both of them off to the Director of Public Prosecutions and he ought to ask the Minister for Community Services and Health to stand down until the Director of Public Prosecutions has made a decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. In support of this motion, let us look at what the opinion says. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that Mr Gear approached the Minister and requested details of fees charged by doctors. The Minister claims that he did not provide the information to Mr Gear personally but we understand it has been conceded by the Minister that the information was handed over with his authority.
The opinion continues:

In our opinion, it is clear that the Minister is an `officer' within the meaning of sub-s. (14) of s. 130 of the Health Insurance Act. The Minister is responsible for the administration of the Act. He performs many duties and exercises many functions under or in relation to the Act. Indeed, the information which was disclosed was acquired at his request in the exercise of his powers as Minister. It follows that the Minister was an officer and was subject to the obligations of confidentiality contained in s. 130.

Much of the public debate which has occurred in relation to whether the Minister breached s. 130 has turned on the question whether he was aware that the information authorised to be supplied contained the provider numbers. However, even if the Minister only authorised communication to Mr Gear of information which did not contain provider numbers, it is our opinion that this constituted a breach of s. 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act.
Another section states:

Therefore, irrespective of whether the provider numbers were disclosed without the Minister's knowledge, there was a breach of s. 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act by the Minister because, in our opinion, there is nothing in the section which makes the disclosure of the identity of a person a necessary precondition of breach.

It follows from our opinion as to the proper construction of s. 130 (1) of the Health Insurance Act that the offence was complete even if the provider numbers were not disclosed. Accordingly, even if the Minister held an honest and reasonable belief that the numbers were not included, this cannot negative the contravention of the section.

In our opinion, the defence of honest and reasonable belief is not available under the provisions of s. 130 (1). First, there is nothing in the language of the section to suggest that the defence is open.

Also, the section does not impose a heavy penalty. Accordingly, in our opinion, the legislature intended by s. 130 (1) is to create an offence of absolute liability. See the discussion in the Kaw Teh v. The Queen (1985) . . .

If our preferred construction of s. 130 (1) is correct, for the reasons already given, we do not think, on the facts as we understand them, that the Minister would have such a defence because apart from the provider numbers, he knew the nature of the offending information. If our view is incorrect and the identifying information must be included in the disclosure to be a breach, there are a number of factors which, in our view, would militate against such a defence being successful.

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a message from the Senate transmitting resolutions relating to parliamentary privilege. The terms of the resolutions will be printed in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: The resolutions read as follows-
PARLIAMENTARY PRIVILEGE
RESOLUTIONS AGREED TO BY THE SENATE ON 25 FEBRUARY 1988
1. Procedures to be observed by Senate committees for the protection of witnesses
That, in their dealings with witnesses, all committees of the Senate shall observe the following procedures:

(1) A witness shall be invited to attend a committee meeting to give evidence. A witness shall be summoned to appear (whether or not the witness was previously invited to appear) only where the committee has made a decision that the circumstances warrant the issue of a summons.

(2) Where a committee desires that a witness produce documents relevant to the committee's inquiry, the witness shall be invited to do so, and an order that documents be produced shall be made (whether or not an invitation to produce documents has previously been made) only where the committee has made a decision that the circumstances warrant such an order.

(3) A witness shall be given reasonable notice of a meeting at which the witness is to appear, and shall be supplied with a copy of the committee's order of reference, a statement of the matters expected to be dealt with during the witness's appearance, and a copy of these procedures. Where appropriate a witness shall be supplied with a transcript of relevant evidence already taken.
(4) A witness shall be given opportunity to make a submission in writing before appearing to give oral evidence.

(5) Where appropriate, reasonable opportunity shall be given for a witness to raise any matters of concern to the witness relating to the witness's submission or the evidence the witness is to give before the witness appears at a meeting.
(6) A witness shall be given reasonable access to any documents that the witness has produced to a committee.

(7) A witness shall be offered, before giving evidence, the opportunity to make application, before or during the hearing of the witness's evidence, for any or all of the witness's evidence to be heard in private session, and shall be invited to give reasons for any such application. If the application is not granted, the witness shall be notified of reasons for that decision.

(8) Before giving any evidence in private session a witness shall be informed whether it is the intention of the committee to publish or present to the Senate all or part of that evidence, that it is within the power of the committee to do so, and that the Senate has the authority to order the production and publication of undisclosed evidence.

(9) A chairman of a committee shall take care to ensure that all questions put to witnesses are relevant to the committee's inquiry and that the information sought by those questions is necessary for the purpose of that inquiry. Where a member of a committee requests discussion of a ruling of the chairman on this matter, the committee shall deliberate in private session and determine whether any question which is the subject of the ruling is to be permitted.

(10) Where a witness objects to answering any question put to the witness on any ground, including the ground that the question is not relevant or that the answer may incriminate the witness, the witness shall be invited to state the ground upon which objection to answering the question is taken. Unless the committee determines immediately that the question should not be pressed, the committee shall then consider in private session whether it will insist upon an answer to the question, having regard to the relevance of the question to the committee's inquiry and the importance to the inquiry of the information sought by the question. If the committee determines that it requires an answer to the question, the witness shall be informed of that determination and the reasons for the determination, and shall be required to answer the question only in private session unless the committee determines that it is essential to the committee's inquiry that the question be answered in public session. Where a witness declines to answer a question to which a committee has required an answer, the committee shall report the facts to the Senate.
(11) Where a committee has reason to believe that evidence about to be given may reflect adversely on a person, the committee shall give consideration to hearing that evidence in private session.

(12) Where a witness gives evidence reflecting adversely on a person and the committee is not satisfied that that evidence is relevant to the committee's inquiry, the committee shall give consideration to expunging that evidence from the transcript of evidence, and to forbidding the publication of that evidence.

(13) Where evidence is given which reflects adversely on a person and action of the kind referred to in paragraph (12) is not taken in respect of the evidence, the committee shall provide reasonable opportunity for that person to have access to that evidence and to respond to that evidence by written submission and appearance before the committee.

(14) A witness may make application to be accompanied by counsel and to consult counsel in the course of a meeting at which the witness appears. In considering such an application, a committee shall have regard to the need for the witness to be accompanied by counsel to ensure the proper protection of the witness. If an application is not granted, the witness shall be notified of reasons for that decision.
(15) A witness accompanied by counsel shall be given reasonable opportunity to consult counsel during a meeting at which the witness appears.

(16) An officer of a department of the Commonwealth or of a State shall not be asked to give opinions on matters of policy, and shall be given reasonable opportunity to refer questions asked of the officer to superior officers or to a Minister.

(17) Reasonable opportunity shall be afforded to witnesses to make corrections of errors of transcription in the transcript of their evidence and to put before a committee additional material supplementary to their evidence.

(18) Where a committee has any reason to believe that any person has been improperly influenced in respect of evidence which may be given before the committee, or has been subjected to or threatened with any penalty or injury in respect of any evidence given, the committee shall take all reasonable steps to ascertain the facts of the matter. Where the committee considers that the facts disclose that a person may have been improperly influenced or subjected to or threatened with penalty or injury in respect of evidence which may be or has been given before the committee, the committee shall report the facts and its conclusions to the Senate.
2. Procedures for the protection of witnesses before the Privileges Committee

That, in considering any matter referred to it which may involve, or gives rise to any allegation of, a contempt, the Committee of Privileges shall observe the procedures set out in this resolution, in addition to the procedures required by the Senate for the protection of witnesses before committees. Where this resolution is inconsistent with the procedures required by the Senate for the protection of witnesses, this resolution shall prevail to the extent of the inconsistency.

(1) A person shall, as soon as practicable, be informed, in writing, of the nature of any allegations, known to the Committee and relevant to the Committee's inquiry, against the person, and of the particulars of any evidence which has been given in respect of the person.
(2) The Committee shall extend to that person all reasonable opportunity to respond to such allegations and evidence by:
(a) making written submission to the Committee;
(b) giving evidence before the Committee;
(c) having other evidence placed before the Committee; and
(d) having witnesses examined before the Committee.

(3) Where oral evidence is given containing any allegation against, or reflecting adversely on, a person, the Committee shall ensure as far as possible that that person is present during the hearing of that evidence, and shall afford all reasonable opportunity for that person, by counsel or personally, to examine witnesses in relation to that evidence.
(4) A person appearing before the Committee may be accompanied by counsel, and shall be given all reasonable opportunity to consult counsel during that appearance.
(5) A witness shall not be required to answer in public session any question where the Committee has reason to believe that the answer may incriminate the witness.
(6) Witnesses shall be heard by the Committee on oath or affirmation.
(7) Hearing of evidence by the Committee shall be conducted in public session, except where:
(a) the Committee accedes to a request by a witness that the evidence of that witness be heard in private session;
(b) the Committee determines that the interests of a witness would best be protected by hearing evidence in private session; or
(c) the Committee considers that circumstances are otherwise such as to warrant the hearing of evidence in private session.
(8) The Committee may appoint, on terms and conditions approved by the President, counsel to assist it.
(9) The Committee may authorise, subject to rules determined by the Committee, the examination by counsel of witnesses before the Committee.

(10) As soon as practicable after the Committee has determined findings to be included in the Committee's report to the Senate, and prior to the presentation of the report, a person affected by those findings shall be acquainted with the findings and afforded all reasonable opportunity to make submissions to the Committee, in writing and orally, on those findings. The Committee shall take such submissions into account before making its report to the Senate.

(11) The Committee may recommend to the President the reimbursement of costs of representation of witnesses before the Committee. Where the President is satisfied that a person would suffer substantial hardship due to liability to pay the costs of representation of the person before the Committee, the President may make reimbursement of all or part of such costs as the President considers reasonable.
(12) Before appearing before the Committee a witness shall be given a copy of this resolution.
3. Criteria to be taken into account when determining matters relating to contempt.

The Senate declares that it will take into account the following criteria when determining whether matters possibly involving contempt should be referred to the Committee of Privileges and whether a contempt has been committed, and requires the Committee of Privileges to take these criteria into account when inquiring into any matter referred to it:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate;
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt; and
(c) whether a person who committed any act which may be held to be a contempt:
(i) knowingly committed that act, or
(ii) had any reasonable excuse for the commission of that act.
4. Criteria to be taken into account by the President in determining whether a motion arising from a matter of privilege should be given precedence of other business

Notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, in determining whether a motion arising from a matter of privilege should have precedence of other business, the President shall have regard only to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.
5. Protection of persons referred to in the Senate
(1) Where a person who has been referred to by name, or in such a way as to be readily identified, in the Senate, makes a submission in writing to the President:

(a) claiming that the person has been adversely affected in reputation or in respect of dealings or association with others, or injured in occupation, trade, office or financial credit, or that the person's privacy has been unreasonably invaded, by reason of that reference to the person; and
(b) requesting that the person be able to incorporate an appropriate response in the parliamentary record,
if the President is satisfied:

(c) that the subject of the submission is not so obviously trivial or the submission so frivolous, vexatious or offensive in character as to make it inappropriate that it be considered by the Committee of Privileges; and
(d) that it is practicable for the Committee of Privileges to consider the submission under this resolution,
the President shall refer the submission to that Committee.

(2) The Committee may decide not to consider a submission referred to it under this resolution if the Committee considers that the subject of the submission is not sufficiently serious or the submission is frivolous, vexatious or offensive in character, and such a decision shall be reported to the Senate.

(3) If the Committee decides to consider a submission under this resolution, the Committee may confer with the person who made the submission and any Senator who referred in the Senate to that person.
(4) In considering a submission under this resolution, the Committee shall meet in private session.

(5) The Committee shall not publish a submission referred to it under this resolution or its proceedings in relation to such a submission, but may present minutes of its proceedings and all or part of such submission to the Senate.
(6) In considering a submission under this resolution and reporting to the Senate the Committee shall not consider or judge the truth of any statements made in the Senate or of the submission.
(7) In its report to the Senate on a submission under this resolution, the Committee may make either of the following recommendations:
(a) that no further action be taken by the Senate or by the Committee in relation to the submission; or
(b) that a response by the person who made the submission, in terms specified in the report and agreed to by the person and the Committee, be published by the Senate or incorporated in Hansard,
and shall not make any other recommendations.
(8) A document presented to the Senate under paragraph (5) or (7):
(a) in the case of a response by a person who made a submission, shall be succinct and strictly relevant to the questions in issue and shall not contain anything offensive in character; and
(b) shall not contain any matter the publication of which would have the effect of:
(i) unreasonably adversely affecting or injuring a person, or unreasonably invading a person's privacy, in the manner referred to in paragraph (1); or
(ii) unreasonably adding to or aggravating any such adverse effect, injury or invasion of privacy suffered by a person.
6. Matters constituting contempts

That, without derogating from its power to determine that particular acts constitute contempts, the Senate declares, as a matter of general guidance, that breaches of the following prohibitions, and attempts or conspiracies to do the prohibited acts, may be treated by the Senate as contempts.
Interference with the Senate
(1) A person shall not improperly interfere with the free exercise by the Senate or a committee of its authority, or with the free performance by a Senator of the Senator's duties as a Senator.
Improper influence of Senators

(2) A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force or threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence a Senator in the Senator's conduct as a Senator or induce a Senator to be absent from the Senate or a committee.
Senators seeking benefits etc.

(3) A Senator shall not ask for, receive or obtain, any property or benefit for the Senator, or another person, on any understanding that the Senator will be influenced in the discharge of the Senator's duties, or enter into any contract, understanding or arrangement having the effect, or which may have the effect, of controlling or limiting the Senator's independence or freedom of action as a Senator, or pursuant to which the Senator is in any way to act as the representative of any outside body in the discharge of the Senator's duties.
Molestation of Senators
(4) A person shall not inflict any punishment, penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, a Senator on account of the Senator's conduct as a Senator.
Disturbance of the Senate

(5) a person shall not wilfully disturb the Senate or a committee while it is meeting, or wilfully engage in any disorderly conduct in the precincts of the Senate or a committee tending to disturb its proceedings.
Service of writs etc.

(6) A person shall not serve or execute any criminal or civil process in the precincts of the Senate on a day on which the Senate meets except with the consent of the Senate or of a person authorised by the Senate to give such consent.
False reports of proceedings
(7) A person shall not wilfully publish any false or misleading report of the proceedings of the Senate or of a committee.
Disobedience of orders
(8) A person shall not, without reasonable excuse, disobey a lawful order of the Senate or of a committee.
Obstruction of orders
(9) A person shall not interfere with or obstruct another person who is carrying out a lawful order of the Senate or of a committee.
Interference with witnesses

(10) A person shall not, by fraud, intimidation, force of threat of any kind, by the offer or promise of any inducement or benefit of any kind, or by other improper means, influence another person in respect of any evidence given or to be given before the Senate or a committee, or induce another person to refrain from giving such evidence.
Molestation of witnesses
(11) A person shall not inflict any penalty or injury upon, or deprive of any benefit, another person on account of any evidence given or to be given before the Senate or a committee.
Offences by witnesses etc.
(12) A witness before the Senate or a committee shall not:
(a) without reasonable excuse, refuse to make an oath or affirmation or give some similar undertaking to tell the truth when required to do so;
(b) without reasonable excuse, refuse to answer any relevant question put to the witness when required to do so; or

(c) give any evidence which the witness knows to be false or misleading in a material particular, or which the witness does not believe on reasonable grounds to be true or substantially true in every material particular.
(13) A person shall not, without reasonable excuse:
(a) refuse or fail to attend before the Senate or a committee when ordered to do so; or
(b) refuse or fail to produce documents, or to allow the inspection of documents, in accordance with an order of the Senate or of a committee.
(14) A person shall not wilfully avoid service of an order of the Senate or of a committee.
(15) A person shall not destroy, damage, forge of falsify any document required to be produced by the Senate or by a committee.
Unauthorised disclosure of evidence etc.
(16) A person shall not, without the authority of the Senate or a committee, publish or disclose:

(a) a document that has been prepared for the purpose of submission, and submitted, to the Senate or a committee and has been directed by the Senate or a committee to be treated as evidence taken in private session or as a document confidential to the Senate or the committee;
(b) any oral evidence taken by the Senate or a committee in private session, or a report of any such oral evidence; or
(c) any proceedings in private session of the Senate or a committee or any report of such proceedings,
unless the Senate or a committee has published, or authorised the publication of, that document, that oral evidence or a report of those proceedings.
7. Raising of matters of privilege
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, a matter of privilege shall not be brought before the Senate except in accordance with the following procedures:
(1) A Senator intending to raise a matter of privilege shall notify the President, in writing, of the matter.

(2) The President shall consider the matter and determine, as soon as practicable, whether a motion relating to the matter should have precedence of other business, having regard to the criteria set out in any relevant resolution of the Senate. The President's decision shall be communicated to the Senator, and, if the President thinks it appropriate, or determines that a motion relating to the matter should have precedence, to the Senate.
(3) A senator shall not take any action in relation to, or refer to, in the Senate, an matter which is under consideration by the President in accordance with this resolution.

(4) Where the President determines that a motion relating to a matter should be given precedence of other business, the Senator may, at any time when there is no other business before the Senate, give notice of a motion to refer the matter to the Committee of Privileges. Such notice shall take precedence of all other business on the day for which the notice is given.

(5) A determination by the President that a motion relating to a matter should not have precedence of other business does not prevent a Senator in accordance with other procedures taking action in relation to, or referring to, that matter in the Senate, subject to the rules of the Senate.

(6) Where notice of a motion is given under paragraph (4) and the Senate is not expected to meet within the period of one week occurring immediately after the day on which the notice is given, the motion may be moved on that day.
8. Motions relating to contempts
That, notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders, a motion to:
(a) determine that a person has committed a contempt; or
(b) impose a penalty upon a person for a contempt,
shall not be moved unless notice of the motion has been given not less than 7 days before the day for moving the motion.
9. Exercise of Freedom of Speech
(1) That the Senate considers that, in speaking in the Senate or in a committee, Senators should take the following matters into account:
(a) the need to exercise their valuable right of freedom of speech in a responsible manner;
(b) the damage that may be done by allegations made in Parliament to those who are the subject of such allegations and to the standing of Parliament;
(c) the limited opportunities for persons other than members of Parliament to respond to allegations made in Parliament;
(d) the need for Senators, while fearlessly performing their duties, to have regard to the rights of others; and
(e) the desirability of ensuring that statements reflecting adversely on persons are soundly based.
(2) That the President, whenever the President considers that it is desirable to do so, may draw the attention of the Senate to the spirit and the letter of this resolution.
10. Reference to Senate proceedings in court proceedings

(1) That, without derogating from the law relating to the use which may be made of proceedings in Parliament under section 49 of the Constitution, and subject to any law and any order of the Senate relating to the disclosure of proceedings of the Senate or a committee, the Senate declares that leave of the Senate is not required for the admission into evidence, or reference to, records or reports of proceedings in the Senate or in a committee of the Senate, or the admission of evidence relating to such proceedings, in proceedings before any court or tribunal.
(2) That the practice whereby leave of the Senate is sought in relation to matters referred to in paragraph (1) be discontinued.

(3) That the Senate should be notified of any admission of evidence or reference to proceedings of the kind referred to in paragraph (1), and the Attorneys-General of the Commonwealth and the State be requested to develop procedures whereby such notification may be given.
11. Consultation between Privileges Committees
That, in considering any matter referred to it, the Committee of Privileges may confer with the Committee of Privileges of the House of Representatives.
