DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Smith had moved by way of amendment:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Hawke Government should be condemned:

(1) for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory; and
(2) for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more interesting contributions during this debate was delivered by the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton). Although he is a member of the Left faction of the Australian Labor Party, which is implacably opposed to the mining and export of uranium in all its forms, he indicated a fatalistic acceptance of the inevitable, apparently because it is a part of ALP policy and for no other reason. He carefully avoided reference to the sale of uranium to France, which is contrary to ALP policy, and which prompted him, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) to walk noisily out of the chamber during the Budget Speech made by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) which announced the resumption of sales of uranium to France. I see that the honourable member for Hindmarsh and the honourable member for La Trobe are nodding in agreement. I would not want to do them any disservice. They have their beliefs, which I respect, but with which, of course, I do not agree.

SPEECH.PARA: One is a little undecided about being either amused or bemused at that omission by the honourable member for La Trobe in not referring to the sale of uranium to France. It is equally easy to become confused because he described as nonsense a claim by my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) about demand for uranium. It seems that electricity generation by nuclear means in Canada, France, the United Kingdom and the United States of America is not to expand, if the opinion of the honourable member for La Trobe is to be accepted. The honourable member, in acknowledging that each of those countries has new reactors under construction, also correctly pointed out that they currently have plans for only two new reactors. I see that he is nodding in agreement, so I am not misrepresenting him on that point. Furthermore, he claimed that, of those under construction, `it will be interesting to see how many of them will be completed', when referring to the considerable numbers of reactors already being built. He gave Three Mile Island and Chernobyl as his reasons for speculating in that way. The news that I have for the honourable member is that the problems of Three Mile Island occurred years before he made his speech. Nothing that has happened since has hindered construction of the quite considerable number of reactors now being built. Unless the honourable member has some divine insight, he and his fellow travellers should abandon that sort of throwaway rhetoric.

Projections of demand published by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and referred to by the honourable member are not of much use, either. Members of the Australian Labor Party cite the OECD on every conceivable matter when it suits an argument. The truth is that the OECD is very helpful in providing figures and historical information. Its forecasts, however, are almost entirely made up of the views and wish lists of the member countries and cannot be taken seriously. Nowhere is this made more plain than in the published OECD estimates of Australia's economic prospects over the past several years which mirror exactly what it was told by the Treasurer and his Department. We all know how wide of the mark the Government has been. Unfortunately, in using the misinformation provided, the OECD has brought itself into disrepute to the extent that is forecasts are not regarded as authoritative.

When honourable members opposite trot out OECD figures which may or may not reflect future demand for uranium, we on this side-and very many others-are far from impressed. The honourable member for La Trobe went on to say that because it is ALP policy it is all right that there are three producing mines in Australia. He properly acknowledged that one is pretty well mined out, with only stock piles of yellowcake to be sold, so it is really a two-mine policy. He went on to say that mining in the Alligator Rivers region is inappropriate. That leaves only Roxby Downs. The honourable member is not really supporting a three-mine policy but a one mine policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No mines at all, if I had my way.

—Exactly. But why did the honourable member not say that in his contribution to this debate? We can respect that point of view without agreeing with it, but the honourable member skirted around the issue. I respect him for his beliefs but I regret that he did not express them in this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Although it is of interest to make some informed and not so informed guesses about the likely demand for uranium, it seems so pointless and unnecessary. That is surely not the job of politicians or governments. The miners and producers can make judgments about that and they undoubtedly would, were it not for restrictions imposed by the Commonwealth. There is no-one in this Parliament or the bureaucracy with the information which equips them to make judgments about the market for uranium products. All I would like to say about growth, or lack of growth, in demand for uranium is that it is more likely to be distorted by interfering governments than by the sellers and consumers of uranium for power generation purposes. Just as important is the fact that it is not the size or growth of the market which is at issue; it is more a matter of Australia's share of the market, whatever its size.

If Australian miners-as we have been confidently told by members on both sides-are cost-efficient producers of uranium, open to competition from within Australia, it is likely that producers could obtain a greater share of the market. It is also true that Australian producers compete against producers from politically un- stable countries such as Nigeria and the Republic of South Africa. Who is to say that consumers would not be prepared to pay a premium, if necessary, for Australian yellowcake because we are a politically stable country with a reputation for reliability-strikes and industrial activity by the waterfront and seamen's unions excepted. Another factor affecting market share for all suppliers is the recent agreement between Canada and the United States which has the effect of tying up the entire North American market for Canadian producers if the letter of the law of that agreement is followed.

The Government says one thing in this area, as it does in others, and does another. Politically, it feels that it cannot adopt those measures which are correct. In this case it would be right to allow the safe mining of any uranium reserves which are commercially viable. It knows that the alternative of the destructionist, anti-mining lobby is wrong. So the Government does nothing-unless some cynical political interest awakens Government members from their slumber as it does from time to time. The influence of the Jean Melzers of the ALP, as well as the Nuclear Disarmament Party senators and the Australian Democrats, has led the Hawke Government to take actions which undermine Australia's international trade, reduce employment, put employers in an untenable position of perpetual uncertainty and even threatens the security of the country. This has the support of a small minority of Australian voters.

The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill involves an increase in the export duty on the tonnage of exported uranium. This is a duty on an export which the Government likes to pretend does not occur, other than in exceptional circumstances. Clearly, such exports should be subject to our obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Additional safeguards are made to ensure that waste disposal and transport of uranium and its derivative products adhere to strict international standards. Under the previous coalition Government we took measures which would have allowed the Australian uranium export industry to become one of the most dynamic contributors to Australian trade as well as having some of the most stringent safeguards in the world. The present Government has not been able constructively to improve on the measures which we put in place when in government. Yet by calling a halt to the development of mining by the termination of negotiating licences, the Government has stopped Australians reaping the benefits from the structure which was already in place. The Hawke-Keating Government made exceptions to its attitude to uranium mining, just as it will always make exceptions for political advantage.

The Bill before us relates to one of those exceptions. The Alligator Rivers mine within the Kakadu National Park has managed to survive because it has been around since 1983. Another exception at Roxby Downs was announced just before the last State election in South Australia. Clearly, the Bannon Government needed whatever help it could get partially to rescue the industry of that State, but the Hawke-Keating Government stooped to what must be the lowest level of pork-barrel politics in support of a political ally. There is no difference in principle between Roxby Downs and such prospects as Yeelirrie in Western Australia, Ben Lomond in Queensland and many other potential mines dotted around the country outside the south-east corner.

This Bill is an example of the discrimination which this Government will apply when making more exceptions to a rule which it does not really believe in. The uranium concentrate export duty under this Bill applies only to uranium mined in one region. The duty is simply a convenient means of providing for the recovery of government costs in monitoring mining. It is said to be an application of the user pays principle, which is so hated when convenient, by the New South Wales division of the ALP under the short-lived Premier, Mr Barrie Unsworth. Yet, the user is not paying by a fee for service under these proposals. The user pays through a duty or tax on the export of a product. If `user-pays' cost recovery means only that extra revenue is raised through normal means to cover the cost of expenditure, it becomes meaningless.

By and large tax revenue must roughly cover government expenditure. For all the talk of `cost recovery', the outcome after passage of this Bill is that it will increase a duty, a tax, on the operations of a company in the mining industry which provides valuable exports. It is an extra cost on the company, imposed by the Government for services which are often not wanted anyway. When the Government raises revenue it should have the dignity, the honesty, to admit it openly. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) should not hide the effect of the Bill behind the rhetoric of cost recovery, as if the Government were providing a valued good or service. Environmental monitoring and government research are not infrastructure like roads, or a service like electricity, for which the user should pay. Indeed, using this duty is a wholly inappropriate means of achieving cost recovery.

As it is, the levy will recover only 75 per cent of the costs of monitoring and research. What would happen if the uranium mining industry were allowed to take the advice of the Minister, who self-righteously tells Australian industry to involve itself in further processing of raw materials? Presumably, monitoring and research of yellowcake production would continue at the same level. Would the enriched uranium be subject to the export duty? What new tax would have to be introduced then, if one were to follow the logic being advanced in support of this measure?

At present Australia does not have a uranium enrichment plant, although we read in the Press today that the Northern Territory Government is very anxious to proceed with one. Very careful consideration should be given to the feasibility of that proposal. A government instrumentality might not be a suitable vehicle, but the enrichment of uranium should certainly be considered by this Government for the betterment of the prospects of all Australians. No-one here will process the raw material of uranium and yellowcake into a product which is immediately useful. A uranium enrichment plant should not be ruled out, therefore, by the Australian Government. It might not be economically feasible, but if it were, such a facility would further improve the returns from a valuable natural resource.

Honourable members opposite should not, as some no doubt will, think of my defence of the peaceful use of uranium as a few throw-away lines for the wealthy corporations which mine uranium. Economic prosperity benefits everyone. The employment generated helps tradesmen, miners, clerks-everyone in our workforce and our community. The Labor Party, when it restricts enterprise, puts directly and indirectly at risk the livelihood of all. The people immediately involved almost always support development.

In the Northern Territory, transport and waterside workers are quite willing to deal with uranium. Yet, time after time, the ALP seems to want to sacrifice these people to the concentrations of voters who mistakenly believe that they have nothing to lose from the distant happenings in mining and rural areas. This is the worst kind of populism. It plays on people's misunderstandings and, in the long run, it undermines the welfare of individuals. No matter how the Government tries to twist the facts about its so-called policy on uranium, it is a policy which has favoured some States and Territories over others. It favours some producers over others. It buys the votes of one group of people with the money and livelihoods of others.

The ALP Government has not objected to uranium mining in principle, as two major mines are now exporting and one other, Roxby Downs, is about to come on line. The Government is very happy to accept the revenue from companies which profitably export uranium. Why should not other firms, other States, other potential workers, share in the benefits of opening new mines? We will never be able to measure the forgone wealth and lost opportunities that uranium mining and the profits from such mining might have offered. The new capital which comes from primary production is desperately needed to boost investment in Australia.

Uranium mining would not be the ultimate solution to all the problems which this country now has, but it would help. We have had enough of simplistic panaceas from the other side of the House. Indeed, the double standards of the Government that are reflected in this Bill, which deals with funding the Government's intervention in uranium mining, are the result of one of these simple solutions. The opponents of uranium mining somehow argue that the miners are ultimately responsible for the emergence of nuclear weapons, the potential accidents in nuclear reactors in distant lands and a range of other so-called sins, in this modern age.

It is very easy to deny the value of nuclear power from the relative comfort of Australia. However, in Japan, Europe or the United States-some of the largest consumers of uranium for peaceful purposes-where enormous amounts of energy are used for heating so that people can continue to live, nuclear power is a necessity. Clearly, coal, solar and other energy sources are no solution. Fossil fuels present problems in themselves, We all know about acid rain in the Northern Hemisphere. Energy is one of those necessities which cannot be abandoned. If Australian firms can be a major supplier of this necessity it is only to the advantage of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Government's proposals before the chamber today in relation to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill. The tariff was increased from 80c to $1.02 per kilogram as from 15 September 1987 on those uranium concentrates produced from the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory. The duty, which has been imposed on uranium since 1980, is partially to offset the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities by the Office of the Supervising Scientist associated with uranium mining operations in the Alligator Rivers region. The increase in the duty proposed in the Bill will recover about 75 per cent of those costs. For those who are interested in this area, the Office of the Supervising Scientist was created in recognition of the special need to protect the environment of the Alligator Rivers region, an area of great beauty and worldwide environmental significance, from the effects of uranium mining operations, both in the short term and the long term.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to focus my remarks on a couple of visits that I made to the United Kingdom in relation to the use of nuclear power. I will make a few comments on some of the issues which are very important to many people in Australia and in other parts of the world. I do not think there has been a product which has had as much debate and as much controversy in its mining and its use as uranium has had since it first came on stream around the late 1930s and early 1940s, particularly its use at the end of the Second World War when two atomic weapons were dropped on Japan. There has been a lot of genuine concern as to how radioactivity would affect the human race and the genes of human beings and how families would be affected. With something new we always have a situation where lack of knowledge can create caution, fear and conservatism in many people, and in this case the question is whether we should move boldly down the path of development of nuclear power and the mining of uranium or whether we should be cautious.

We have had an enormous debate on this issue in Australia over many years. It has been a very contentious debate, particularly in the Australian Labor Party (ALP). The Labor Party has always had a policy of mining uranium. There was a strong move in the debating areas to try to change that policy. It was not successful. As has been expounded by this House many times, we still have a policy of moving forward cautiously in mining uranium; we will sell it cautiously to the world where we are assured that there are safeguards on its use and that it will be used for peaceful purposes and will not find its way into the development of nuclear weapons.

On my first visit to the United Kingdom I was very interested to see just how nuclear waste was being disposed of. I went to probably the most contentious area in the debate; that is, Sellafield, which is on the west coast of the United Kingdom, closest to the Irish coast. There has been a lot of contention in relation to how nuclear waste is being handled in that part of the world. I am the first to admit, from going there, that mistakes have been made in the past. There was a serious fire in the 1950s. At that stage, when there was not much public knowledge made available of the nuclear industry, a lot of problems did occur; and they are problems which are still being investigated. I believe that over the period-and I came to this conclusion very strongly-that we have seen the development of nuclear power in the world there has been an extreme move on the conservative side to guarantee safety as much as possible. I think that is evident from the statistical figures of those who have died as a result of nuclear accidents, compared with other areas of power generation throughout the world.

I think the extreme caution is to be commended. I pay tribute to those people throughout the world who have fought very hard to get those safety measures, bearing in mind that until the 1960s it was a very secretive industry. There was not much discussion as to the future of nuclear power and there was a lot of caution and conservatism. People were not taken into confidence by the powers in command at the time in the industry. I think they are paying the price for that right now in the late 1980s and going into the 1990s-there is a lot of mistrust of organisations which are heavily involved in the nuclear industry.

My concerns were to look at what was happening with nuclear waste and what we were doing with it. Its final depository is still a major problem throughout the world. However, I am convinced that the methods that are being adopted throughout the world are such that the scientific capacity is there to overcome the problems. There is still a long way to go in relation to urgency for the disposal of high level waste because of the small amounts that are being controlled around the world. There is a more urgent reason to look at the way of disposing of the mid-level waste; that is, the not so highly toxic pieces of material and equipment that are being used within the process and that are still being stored at present in drums around the world. It still has not been decided where it will go.

I have always been concerned about the publicity that the industry receives around the world and some of the issues that occur. I was in the United Kingdom when a big test was made. Containers were used to transport the rods from the power station to Sellafield for final stripping and disposal. I was in the United Kingdom when a test was made of one of these containers. The rods are taken from the power station and are put into a container made from steel and concrete. Once they are locked inside that container, they are immersed in what is virtually a massive swimming pool. Provided there are five feet of water over that container it is absolutely 100 per cent safe as far as radioactive release is concerned. There is no danger to anybody.

A lot of concern has been expressed around the world about these large swimming pools. They are built on ground level; they are made from concrete and steel. It has been found that over time there is the possibility of their leaking. If there is a slight reduction, minute though it may be, in the amount of water in these massive pools, the headline is that there will be a nuclear waste leak at some power station. The water is quite pure and is checked every day. There is no radioactivity actually in the water. It is as good as any water one would find anywhere and it is monitored and kept in order. The water at that power station has been known to leak at times, but it is quite harmless.

When I went to the Sellafield site the people there were aware of the problem and of the fears that people have. A completely new structure was being developed and has now been completed. I went back to have a look at the completed project. These steel and concrete containers with the rods in them that have been used in the power stations are now in a container of an astronomical size. The investment is enormous. The whole project has been built on stilts. The container now holds thousands and thousands of these steel containers. The water inside those containers is purer than the water that Londoners drink. If honourable members have had a cup of tea in London they will realise that that does not say a great deal for the water. But the water is pure and is not a risk to health. For safety reasons, these containers have been built on stilts. There is no way that any leakage could occur from that container without it being recognised and being collected at another point underneath it. So the efforts of people around the world to impose their views on safety have been heard. There is a massive investment being imposed on the nuclear power industry, which is adding to the cost and making the industry fight hard for its competitive position. But it is being made so safe and so much is being spent on it that I am quite confident that there is no chance that that area alone could cause any problems, even if there was a water leak from that container.

I also looked at the area of high level waste disposal. If honourable members have had the opportunity to look at a nuclear rod of six feet in length they will know that 3 per cent is eventually what is called high level waste. A nuclear rod is about as thick as a finger and is inside a stainless steel container, and 3 per cent at the end of the rod has to be stored as high level waste. When I was there the last container of seven was being built at the site where the high level waste is being disposed of. It is extracted from the rods in the reprocessing plant. After the rods have been processed the 3 per cent liquid high level waste then goes into a stainless steel container. I will describe it for honourable members: it is a building which now houses the total 30-year supply of the United Kingdom's waste plus a fair supply of waste from other countries, all of which is being reprocessed on the one site. It is inside a concrete bunker-type building, which was fascinating to walk into because I was able to see the last one that was being built. From now on the waste is being taken out of the process and going into vitrification, into glass, which is the next process that is required before it is finally stored away at some time in the next century.

To get into this chamber and see where the high level waste was stored we went through a concrete wall which would have been 4 feet 6 inches thick. Then there was a space of about 12 feet, another concrete wall 4 feet 6 inches thick and then a chamber, about half the size of this chamber, in which there were two massive stainless steel tanks one inch thick. Inside one of those tanks the liquid waste was stored. Each of those tanks had a backup cooling system. If the water did not circulate through the stainless steel tank, that high level waste would heat up, eventually to the point where it would split the tank. So there were three systems, those two backups and the one that was operating, which could automatically take up the operation if there were a safety problem due to one of them breaking down.

In the event that all three backup systems broke down, the bunker itself inside the concrete container had wall linings of stainless steel one inch thick and a floor lining of stainless steel one inch thick. All gravitated to a central point, where there was another series of pumps in case everything went wrong and the tanks split. It would then pick up the waste and put it into a spare tank in that very container. Both of those tanks cost #100m to build. One sat empty at all times as a backup for the one in operation. So there were seven of those tanks constructed inside the bunkers and they held the total supply of the high level waste which had been processed at that plant.

At the moment the plant is spending in investment #1.2 billion per day-not all on site, but a lot of it on site-in building thermal oxide reprocessing plant, or THORP as it is called, which is another stage in reprocessing. In that plant it will also be developing the vitrification plant, where the high level waste from the first tank, which was built 30 years ago, would be extracted, put through the glass process and into storage, with just air circulating through the vitrified glass, which is the process required for the next stage. At some time, in about the year 2010 or 2020, the quantity of waste will be such that the plant will then have to dispense with that vitrification process and store the waste somewhere in the world. That decision will be taken probably 30 years from now.

That is a very interesting subject to study and to look into. I fully understand and appreciate the conservative attitude that people have. If people did not have that approach I do not think we would see the great safety measures that are being developed in relation to this very important issue. Nothing would be more harmful to an industry like the nuclear industry than to have repeats of Chernobyl or Three Mile Island, bearing in mind that the Three Mile Island incident did not cause a single fatality. But people died because of Chernobyl, a lot from burns received on the site and some who were affected by radiation. I do not think there is any way that we will go backwards and see the nuclear industry put aside. Forty democratically elected governments have decided, by free vote, that they will have nuclear power.

Australia of course has the largest proportion of the actual source of supply of uranium, but that does not mean we should take a position which is irresponsible and which should not take into account the views of members of the general public who have concerns and who want to be assured that future generations will not be affected by incorrect decisions made in haste. Whilst I believe we now have a great opportunity to supply the markets of the world with uranium, we should not rush in. The supply is not going to go away. It is an asset that Australia has and, unless there is an invasion and somebody takes it from us, it will be in our control and we can decide when and where we sell it and what safety measures we put upon it. I think we have a great responsibility. I think it is a good thing that in this nation, Australia, with 16 million people, we have a government and people who are concerned and who need to be assured that, while we are still moving down the path of having a policy on mining and selling uranium for peaceful purposes, our uranium will not end up in nuclear weapons. There is an enormous debate going on in the world about that. Can we really be assured that it cannot happen?

I take the view that quite clearly there is a need in this world for this type of power generation. There is a need for this technology to advance. I hope that one day the experts and the scientists will develop even safer ways of using nuclear power than we have at present. But we have to go step by step and proceed with caution. That is why I am very pleased that, although those of us on this side of the House concede that there are supplies of uranium, we are certainly not going to open the floodgates and say that just because we have the opportunity to sell thousands of tonnes we will sell them to anybody who thinks that it should be sold.

With those few comments, I support the legislation before the House. I am sure that the extra money collected by this duty will go towards very good measures in Australia and that the Supervising Scientist will put the money to good use. This is just part of the ongoing policies of this Government. It will not be stampeded into decision-making in relation to this matter. We want to be absolutely sure that, while we are progressive, we err on the side of conservatism in relation to the future development of nuclear power.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Act 1980. The purpose of the Bill is to increase the levy that is imposed on uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory from 80c to $1.02c per kilogram. This duty commenced at the higher rate on 15 September last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I take part in this debate for four principal reasons. Firstly, because I acknowledge and recognise the importance of the nuclear power industry to development and progress in the world. Secondly, I acknowledge the essential role of government to ensure that there are adequate levels of research in all areas of human endeavour. Thirdly, I take part in the debate because my re-election to this House in 1972, as the member for Sturt, led to the third mine that honourable members have been talking about in this debate. For, in my election in 1972 as a Liberal member, I defeated a Labor member, Norm Foster, who had been the member for Sturt for three years. Following his defeat he became a member of the Legislative Council in South Australia. It was as a result of his courageous vote in support of legislation proposed by the Tonkin Liberal Government that the Roxby Downs indenture Bill was passed. We have been talking about the present Government's three-mine policy, and one of those mines in Roxby Downs. So in some small and indirect way it may have been my electoral success in 1972 that led to a very important decision being taken in South Australia. In other circumstances-if it had not been for the subsequent election of Norm Foster to the Legislative Council of the South Australian Parliament-that decision may not have been taken. The fourth reason I take part in this debate is that for a period while I was Minister for Home Affairs and Environment I had responsibility for the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers region.

I want to focus attention upon that question. The Office of the Supervising Scientist was set up as a result of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry into the Ranger developments in the Alligator Rivers region. It was given certain objectives. In fact, by agreement between the Commonwealth and Northern Territory governments regulation of the mining industry in the Alligator Rivers region is carried out to the maximum extent possible through the laws of the Northern Territory, with the Supervising Scientist exercising only supervisory and coordinating roles in addition to a research role. Essentially, under the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act, the Supervising Scientist is required to do five things: firstly, to carry out research on the effects of uranium and other mining operations on the environment of the Alligator Rivers region, research within a narrow frame into the effects of the mining in that region; secondly, to supervise the implementation of the Commonwealth's and other environmental requirements which mining developments must meet; thirdly, to develop and promote standards, procedures and measures for the protection and restoration of the environment from the effects of mining operations; fourthly, to coordinate environment protection, research and supervisory activities relating to the uranium mining industry in the region; and fifthly, to advise the Minister on these matters.

The point I want to emphasise is that the focus of the functions and role of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is the Alligator Rivers region and mining in that region. Whilst I recognise that general research into the nuclear industry is something in which Australia should be involved, I do not believe that the role of the Supervising Scientist should be subverted to give him a generalist research role that should be carried out by others. His role is region specific. It is for that reason that I support the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), which states:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Hawke Government should be condemned:

(1) for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region, the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory; and
(2) for the imposition of this additional levy on uranium at a time when Australian uranium exporters are struggling to remain competitive on world markets'.

Ten years have gone by since the Office of the Supervising Scientist was established. I would have thought that in that time he and his staff could have had the opportunity to develop and promote the standards and procedures that are required to protect and preserve that region. I would have thought that in 10 years he could have developed programs and plans for the supervision and implementation of the requirements the Commonwealth sets for the mining of uranium in that region. I would have thought that he could have developed strategies and plans for the coordination of the environment, protection, research and supervisory activities in that region. Remember that it is not the role of the Supervising Scientist actually to carry out the monitoring of the regulations. That is being carried out by Northern Territory officers under the supervision of the Supervising Scientist. But he is a supervising scientist to supervise those who have the responsibility for the proper monitoring and environmental protection of that area.

That being the case, I ask: Why is it necessary for the head office of the Office of the Supervising Scientist to be located in Sydney? Whilst there might have been good reasons at the time his office was first established for having the head office in Sydney, the time has long since passed when the base of his operations should be in the region or at least in the Territory where the region is located. I would have thought that it would have been much cheaper for the Australian taxpayer in general and for the uranium industry in particular to have the office closer to the region. I would have thought also that over that 10 years and with the fulfilment of a large number of the responsibilities that were given to the Office of the Supervising Scientist, instead of continuing in his annual report to comment upon the size of his staff and to look to increasing it, he should be telling governments how he could effectively decrease his staff to carry out those supervisory, monitoring and standard setting roles and to carry out research that is region specific. I assume that over 10 years he has carried out a lot of successful research. The scientists I met seemed competent and capable and seemed to be producing adequate papers and material identifying the sort of scientific information that that research was designed to carry out.

Having done that, why do we need to have this region specific organisation on such a huge basis? We find that he has a staff at present of either 68 or 69, 42 of whom are located in the Northern Territory and 26 in Sydney. Of the 69 staff, 40 are research scientists. Why are they not all in the Northern Territory, based in Darwin or in the Kakadu National Park? The Kakadu National Park is very different now from what it was 10 years ago. It is a beautiful World Heritage area and needs to be monitored, maintained and preserved so that we get balanced development, the appropriate exploitation of the mineral resources in a manner which preserves the environmental beauty of that area. I do not think people dispute that fact. One of our growing industries is tourism, and where do tourists go when they come to Australia? One of the major attractions shown on tourist publicity brochures is Kakadu National Park. There has been a huge increase in the number of people wanting to go to the Northern Territory and visit the national park. The national park's facilities have been improved and they are being supervised in a manner which is designed to preserve the park values for future generations of tourists. Just as we are expecting the Supervising Scientist to develop plans that enable mining to proceed, at the same time we are expecting it to be done in a way which preserves the park so that it is available for future generations.

I am a great supporter of Australia's investment in research in general. I am a great supporter of Australia's involvement in a comprehensive research program where we ensure that the humanities, the sciences-the applied sciences as well as the more theoretical abstract research-are funded in a proper way. But it should not be through the Office of the Supervising Scientist that Australia carries out its nuclear research. The research that is carried out through the Office of the Supervising Scientist is, by its legislation, required to be area and region specific and the research that he carries out should be limited to that. To the extent that Australia wants to have general research into nuclear issues, that research should go through and be tested by the Australian Research Council and get its proper priority in the context of Australia's overall research program. In any event, why should Ranger uranium, the Kakadu National Park uranium, pay a special levy to fund research of a general nature? If we want an industry to provide its research funds on a user pays basis, the tax, the customs duty, should not be an area specific customs duty, as is proposed in this legislation. On the other hand, if we believe that our research should be funded by the general tax imposed on individuals and on corporations then the general research into the nuclear industry should be funded in that way.

If we look at the expenditure of the Office of the Supervising Scientist we find that in 1986-87 it was $6.1m, of which $4.67m was for research. Under $500,000 was spent on supervision and assessment and about $1m on coordination and corporate support-I suppose that is administration. If $6m was spent on research, was it all region specific? I doubt it. We have created an office with the specific purpose of satisfying the recommendations of the Fox inquiry. It had the specific purpose of ensuring that as mining development went on in one of the most beautiful parts of Australia it was done in a way that the park values were preserved. We wanted to ensure that because of the high risk, the relatively high dangers of mining radioactive substances, those park values were not in any way degraded. So, we appointed the Office of Supervising Scientist. We gave him certain roles, but over the years the roles have changed and his research base has extended. I think that is inappropriate.

It is my view that the time has come when the Office of the Supervising Scientist should be subjected to an external review. The purpose of the external review should be to ask, firstly, whether the role he is performing is within the narrow framework of the legislation that established his office. Secondly, the external review should examine the question of the extent to which the research that is being carried on is essential and necessary to the fulfilment of the objectives of the preservation of Kakadu National Park or whether it is of a more general nature, albeit on nuclear research. If it falls into the latter category, then $2m, $3m, or $1m of the research money now going to the Office of the Supervising Scientist should go to the Australian Research Council and those who are interested in nuclear research should then have their proposals for research tested along with researches into cancer, researches into other forms of medical science, researches into engineering and researches into the humanities. Otherwise, over time we will create other offices like the Office of the Supervising Scientist and our research effort will then lack the balance that hopefully will be given to it throughout the Australian Research Council.

I do not criticise the sincerity and the level of dedication of those who discharge their duties as members of the staff of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. However, I do believe that that Office was set up originally with a specific purpose in mind. After 10 years, many of the purposes for which the Office of the Supervising Scientist was set up should have been established, certainly all the initial investment in enabling the monitoring and supervisory roles to be carried out. If it has not been completed in 10 years, it will never be completed. That is why I think we should now have that external review so that Parliament can be advised whether the job has been done. If it has been done then the general research role should be transferred to other areas.

Implicit in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bass is the suggestion that much of this research might well be effectively carried out at the University College of the Northern Territory and many of the other supervisory roles might now, with the growth and experience and maturity of the Government of the Northern Territory, properly be considered for transfer to that Territory Government. I hasten to add, I believe there will be a continuing need for Commonwealth involvement and responsibility in this area for a long time to come, but the day to day work could easily be carried out by competent officers of the Northern Territory Government.

While I support the legislation, I want to see the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bass carried because I think the time has come for us to ensure that the levy imposed upon one uranium producer is set at a level that is sufficient to discharge the responsibilities related to the area in which that producer is operating. If we want to levy the nuclear industry for general research, then the levy should be imposed upon all producers or, alternatively, the funds come from the more traditional sources-and this is what I favour. I do not particularly favour the hypothecation of any particular tax to discharge a nominated role but rather to gather from the general tax base the funds needed to carry out the research role that this country wants fulfilled, recognising that we are a small country, a country with a small population and limited resources. Therefore, we have to make sure our research is comprehensive and, then having determined that it will cover a wide range, within each area of the range we have to be specific with a view to achieving good and effective results in contributing to the overall research that is going on amongst the developed countries of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill I oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition that would seek to limit the role of the Supervising Scientist. The last thing we need to do in this field is limit the work of the Supervising Scientist. I was tempted to respond in this debate to the speech by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) who touched on a number of issues I would like to canvass as arguments or reasons why the role of the Supervising Scientist should not be diminished in any way. The honourable member for Curtin referred to the Roxby Downs venture in South Australia. In response to the points he made on that, I raise the question of the cost to the taxpayers, particularly of South Australia, of the infrastructure of Roxby Downs. Quite frankly, I think it is a scandal that taxpayers' money should be invested to supply the infrastructure for a mining venture which in my view is certainly dubious and not the kind of venture we should seek to put moneys into. On this occasion I would have to agree with the principle of user pays. I would like to see the Western Mining Corporation pay for the infrastructure that is Roxby Downs and we would see then if there was an almighty rush to dig up uranium and further pollute this planet.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issues that were canvassed went to this question of the end uses of uranium. The point that prompted me was the argument canvassed that apart from Chernobyl there have been no recent problems we should be concerned about. Those who canvass that kind of argument should look at this morning's Canberra Times. I cannot give the House the page number but the headline to which I refer read, `N-plant shuts down after two days'. I think it is significant because if technology is as advanced and as safe as some would say, then this kind of thing surely could not happen-but it did. The report in the newspaper, which came from New York, went on to say:
The United States' most expensive nuclear plant shut down automatically last night-just two days after being opened permanently.
The double nuclear power plant automatically shut down when a water pump malfunctioned, a plant official said.
Officials described shut-down of the $US6.3 billion ($A8.63 billion) facility as an unusual event.
Let us hope that kind of thing is very unusual. The article continued:

Mr Robert Burtch, spokesman for the Niagara Mohawk Power Corp, said the problem happened at 5.45 p.m. yesterday, when the plant lost its main feed water pump, which provides water pressure to the reactor.
I interpose there to say that one could be forgiven for thinking that this article was part of the script of the film The China Syndrome. The report continued:
The plant was operating at 99 per cent power but when that [the water pump] tripped, the water level in the reactor dropped and caused the plant to automatically shut down.

Later in the report it was stated that the 1,088- megawatt plant, which was meant to have been completed in 1977 at a cost of $US423m and was opened only very recently, had to close because of the accident. These incidents, which occur constantly, need to be brought to the attention of the community to arrive at a proper balance in any debate on the question of nuclear power. This was not an isolated incident. One could go on and on. So that I cannot be accused of bias in my arguments I wish also to refer to an article that appeared in the Australian on 29 January this year. The article, a Reuters report from the Times, which carries the headline `Soviet protest blocks new N-plant', reads:
MOSCOW: Public protests in the wake of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster have, reportedly, for the first time halted construction of an atomic power station in the Soviet Union.

The Soviet youth party paper . . . said yesterday that the authorities had decided late last year to stop building a plant in Krasnodar, a city in the northern Caucasus, and almost all atomic Soviet plants under construction or already built were opposed by local residents.

It said the world's worst nuclear accident at Chernobyl, which caused 31 deaths and the evacuation of more than 130,000 people from areas around the Ukrainian plant in April 1986, had provoked a `chain reaction' of opposition to nuclear power.
The whole world is talking about Chernobyl . . . The 20 operating stations and nearly all those under construction are bitterly opposed by residents.
Construction of the Krasnodar station was stopped after 25 million roubles ($57.54 million) had been spent on the project, it said.

The protest movement against nuclear power is indeed worldwide. The reasons why we should be much more cautious about the rush to nuclear power and more protective of the role of organisations such as the Office of the Supervising Scientist are dealt with in perhaps one of the most frightening articles one could read on this subject. The article appeared in the Melbourne Age on 11 March under the headline, `40,000 extra deaths in US after Chernobyl'. I shall read that headline again; it is quite stark: `40,000 extra deaths in US after Chernobyl'. The author of the article is Peter Kellner. When reading the article I shall refer to the statistics that the author referred to. The article reads:
I have recently been looking through some remarkable calculations being published by the New Jersey Medical School about the effects of the Chernobyl disaster.

The New Jersey study is mainly the work of Dr Jay Gould, one of the United States' foremost data base statisticians. Dr Gould's expertise involves the computer analysis of population data. In the late 1970s, he served on the Science Advisory Board of President Carter's Environmental Protection Agency.

A few months ago, as the 1986 mortality figures became available across the US state-by-state and month-by-month, Dr Gould started analysing them to see if Chernobyl had caused any variation. It had. Between May and August 1986-the four months immediately following Chernobyl-between 30,000 and 40,000 more people died than was normal for that time of the year; more than 690,000, compared with the 650-660,000 who usually die in the summer months.

Could this difference be simply a statistical freak, signifying nothing? On average, 31.7 per cent of all deaths in America occur in the summer months; 1986's figure was 33.1 per cent. Why make any big deal out of that 1.4 per cent variation? The reason is that the seasonal mortality pattern in America has proved to be remarkably stable. Monthly statistics go back to the beginning of the century and 33.1 per cent is higher than any previous year on record. The chances of it having been a statistically random event are less than one in a million.

So it is as certain as anything in statistics can ever be that something happened to kill an extra 30,000 or more people in America during the summer of 1986. Yet Chernobyl detonated half-way around the world. More evidence is needed to find a connection between that nuclear accident and the American mortality figures.
Dr Gould believes he has found that evidence. There is no dispute that fallout from Chernobyl reached the United States in early May.

The article then reported on the radioactive iodine, I-131, levels recorded in the United States of America. I commend that article to all honourable members and to the public as something that we should think about more seriously. It is far too easy to say that Chernobyl killed 31 people and caused the evacuation of so many others. I believe the report goes to the basis of the problem of nuclear power. It is obvious that at this point in time we are not able to cope with that kind of accident. The report is not an isolated one. In the Adelaide Advertiser of 30 August 1986 a Reuters report appeared with the following headline: `Report lists 3000 nuclear mishaps in US'. The article reads:
US nuclear power plants had nearly 3000 mishaps last year, 23 p.c. more than the previous year, a private energy monitoring group has revealed.

The Public Citizens' Critical Mass Energy Project says in a report that in the past two years 18 nuclear accidents have been so serious the Nuclear Regulatory Commission (NRC) had to report them to Congress.
`There is every reason to believe that an accident as serious as Chernobyl can happen here,' project director Ken Bosson says.

Mr Bosson says information obtained through the Freedom of Information Act and the NRC show that in 1984 and 1985, US reactors came close to catastrophic accidents on several occasions. Emergency shutdowns last year totalled 750, a 28 p.c. rise since 1984.

Again I refer to the article in the Canberra Times this morning detailing a similar accident reported only this morning and in addition to the statistics. On the question of the disposal of these radioactive wastes from the nuclear industry I want to touch on an experience I had in Japan in 1983 when leading a parliamentary delegation there. We had the opportunity to meet with the Japanese atomic energy people and found them most cooperative in the information they were prepared to give us. They gave us a document on the safety of sea dumping of low level radioactive wastes. They were, at that time, waiting for the report from Europe dealing with sea dumping of nuclear wastes. I am glad to say that that report came down against it, but it left the Japanese Government with the problem that it revealed to us when we were there.

I covered this matter in the report I gave to the House on returning with that parliamentary delegation. But it is important and relevant enough that I should touch on it again to show the degree of the problem we have with the nuclear industry. I am going to be talking about low level waste. The document with which the Japanese Government provided us talked about low level waste and included diagrams of the 44-gallon drums, or 200-litre drums, which it was going to use to dispose of this low level waste. The low level waste consisted of waste hand towels, gloves, overalls and anything that may have been in contact with radioactive sources. The material was to be burnt down to ash before being cemented in these drums and disposed of in the sea. The Japanese have so many of these drums of radioactive waste that, quite frankly, they do not know what to do with them.

In a Press release of December 1982, the Japanese Atomic Energy Commission admitted that the Government was actively involved in a publicity campaign aimed at winning public acceptance in Japan, as well as in the Pacific island countries, of the necessity and safety of ocean dumping of low level radioactive waste and is currently undertaking research and tests designed to improve the techniques for safety evaluation of inland disposal. The Press release also recorded that at 31 March 1982 there were approximately 410,000 units of low level radioactive waste, each unit being equivalent to a 200-litre drum. That means that almost half a million drums are stored in Japan's nuclear power sites. It was forecast that, at the current rate of waste accumulation, 1.1 million units would be stored for disposal by 1990. That means there will be 1.1 million 44-gallon drums of low level waste. The Japanese will not know what to do with them. The document provided by the Japanese Government states:
2 days after the visit to the Agency an editorial appeared in the Asahi Evening News-
which is a Japanese newspaper printed in English-
entitled `Nuclear power generation' and it canvassed some of the points raised in the discussions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their contribution to what has been a very long and what I think can be fairly described as a wide-ranging debate. Community attitudes in Australia about nuclear matters have changed very dramatically from a spirit of euphoria and critical acceptance of the British atomic tests in Australia in the 1950s. I thought I would share what is a bit of a period piece, something that happened in this House back in 1956. I will quote from the book Maralinga by Adrian Tame and F. P. J. Robotham. I will read from page 10:

SPEECH.PARA: The Melbourne Argus of 27 September 1956 captured the mood-
of euphoria, that is-

best with its coverage of the Maralinga test . . . `Bombs Away!' trumpeted the paper's front-page headline, followed by the immortal first paragraph: `Maralinga, Thursday: The atom bomb's gone up at last.' Worse was to follow. `Minutes after the explosion, Government members cheered and Labor MPs shouted: ``Thank goodness,'' and ``At last, at last,'' as Mr Beale-
the father of the honourable member for Deakin-

Supply Minister, announced in the House of Representatives the test had been successful.' Still later in the story the euphoria and hysteria increased: `As the cloud [radioactive] faded, convoys of trucks and jeeps brought back the servicemen who'd faced the blast at close range. AND EVERY FACE WORE A SMILE. [Their capitals, not ours.] They could have been coming back from a picnic.'

Thirty-two years on, I do not think that one could quite get away with that spirit of enthusiasm. Having said that, I have to say that the Government will not accept the second reading amendment of the Opposition. First, taking the latter part of the Opposition's amendment, dealing with the imposition of a levy of uranium mining, I want to make it clear that this Government, like the Fraser Government before it, is committed to ensuring that the Kakadu National Park is fully protected from any possible effects of uranium mining operations. Accordingly, in 1978, the Fraser Government decided, in view of the international environmental significance of the Alligator Rivers region, that uranium mining operations which may adversely affect the environment should be subject to oversight by the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS) of the Alligator Rivers Region. Subsequently, by legislation passed in 1980, a levy of 11c per kilogram was imposed on uranium exports in recognition of the special costs of environmental monitoring and research activities related to the uranium mining in the region. The levy recovered only a small fraction of the cost of the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

It has now become an accepted principle of government that the costs of providing necessary regulatory services should be recovered. Accordingly, the Government increased the levy on uranium oxide mined in the Alligator Rivers region in the 1986-87 Budget from 11c to 80c per kilogram while in the 1987-88 Budget the Government increased the levy to $1.02 per kilogram. The Government does not believe that the export levy will significantly affect the competitive position of companies mining uranium in the Alligator Rivers region as the amount raised is small compared with the amount of money made on uranium already mined pursuant to existing contracts. Rather, the Government submits that the amount raised is a very small price to pay to protect a part of Australia's heritage that is of international significance.

The second ground of complaint from the Opposition, relating to the supposed need to limit the role and functions of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, is also rejected. As to the role and duties of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, I want to emphasise that the Government is determined, first, to ensure the highest standard of protection of the Alligator Rivers region, which includes Kakadu National Park, and, second, to be confident in the assurances it gives to the world that the whole region is in fact being so protected. Accordingly, some form of independent, credible scientific advice continues to be required. The OSS is a key element in the environmental protection arrangements put in place by the Government. As I have said, it is not too dissimilar from the provisions already put down by the Fraser Government. The legislative functions and responsibilities of the OSS have been determined by the Commonwealth as being the minimum necessary to enable the Government to assure this Parliament and the public that a sufficiently high standard of environmental protection is being achieved. This is a region not just of national significance but of international significance.

The structure of the OSS, and its research program in particular, is based on the program endorsed by the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. Its programs have been reviewed and endorsed on a number of occasions, including by Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) scientists, as well as by the Australian Science and Technology Council. Its research program is also reviewed regularly by the Co-ordinating Committee for the Alligator Rivers Region, which provides a forum in which all interested parties-including the various uranium mining companies, the unions and the traditional Aboriginal owners-have the opportunity to raise any reservations about the conduct or direction of the work of the OSS. The research program is directly related to the practice of environmental protection, assessment, control and monitoring, and to the provision to the community of technically sound advice on the state of protection being achieved in the region.

The high level of protection of Kakadu National Park from pollution from any of the uranium mines which has been achieved to date testifies to the success of measures and standards being developed and applied by the OSS. It seems to me to be a grotesque reading of that to say, `Well, that shows we don't need it'. In fact, I think it is a tribute to the OSS, and there is no guarantee that if the OSS were removed the same level of environmental respect would remain.

Prominent research activities of the OSS include water and tailings management, geomorphological studies that provide information necessary to ensure that tailings can be contained and isolated from the environment for thousands of years, and the development of strategies for the revegetation of decommissioned mine sites. OSS work has helped keep radiation exposure of the public and workers well below national and international health limits. The OSS program has been strategically applied to major potential environmental impacts arising from uranium mining, both during operations and, even more particularly, in the long term. The job of the OSS does not end with baseline studies, though: the job of monitoring the environment is continuous. As the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) noted, the baseline studies by OSS related to uranium operations, although a prominent earlier element of OSS work, now comprise only a minor component of the institution's work.

The present emphasis on problems arising during the operational phase of mining in the region and on long term environmental considerations is entirely consistent with the statutory role of the OSS and with the research directions envisaged by the Fox inquiry. That, I think, is the fundamental fallacy that was expressed by the Opposition in its case against the OSS. There were in a sense two conflicting points of view-one that it should be dealt with on the micro level, and the other that it should be dealt with on the macro level. The amendment put up by the honourable member for Bass approaches it from a micro point of view. It condemns the Hawke Government-pretty strong language-by saying:

. . . the Hawke Government should be condemned . . . for its failure to limit the role, the duties and the accountability of the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the light of 10 years' experience in its monitoring of the Alligator Rivers region . . .
I would have thought that it was an extraordinary non sequitur to say, `Well, we have done it successfully for 10 years; that is enough'. That argument does not follow. The amendment goes on:
. . . the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory-
I cannot understand why the Opposition has not mentioned the adoption of the Northern Territory flag, the emblem and the territorial flower, because they are about as relevant-
and the establishment of the University College of the Northern Territory;

The University College of the Northern Territory is not, as I understand it, jumping up and down saying, `We have got to do it, it has to be ours'. I am by no means opposed to the future development of capacity in the region, and no doubt the University College will be involved at some future stage, but the infrastructure, the capacity and the personnel requirements need to be planned first and put in place.

In a thoughtful speech-thoughtful, but I think also missing the point-the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson) looked at the macro level and said, `Oh, well, this can all be done by the Australian Research Council'. There are a couple of puzzling things about that. He spoke of the Australian Research Council (ARC) as if it were an organisation which initiated and executed research. The ARC will be essentially a granting body. It will make some contribution towards setting priorities but it will not be initiating or executing research in the way that the CSIRO, the Defence Science and Technology Organisation or ANSTO do. The result is that those jobs that are essentially research projects relating to monitoring are, it has to be said, not the kinds of projects that would concern people who are avid for promotion and eager for post-doctoral status, fellowships and so on. They are not concerned with all that monitoring stuff, which is difficult, and often tedious, involving simply doing the same kind of thing over and over again. I would think it very unlikely, even if we said that we would put $2m for the development of the nuclear industry into the ARC budget, that any project of this nature would be funded in that way. It really has to be thought out.

What I thought was really puzzling was this sense of saying, `Well, we think it's got to be done, as long as it is done by somebody else. It mustn't be done by this mob. We do think it should be done, it should be done somewhere, but we are not too sure where it ought to be done-by the University College of the Northern Territory of the ARC, or somewhere else. But it is not to be done by this organisation.' I thought that thinking was a bit bizarre. When the honourable member for Bass spoke last week I kept thinking of that line about the Irishman who said that the famous plays were not written by William Shakespeare but somebody else with the same name. We all agree that it should be done-as long as it is not done by the guys who are doing it, who have got the proven capacity in this field. That is a bizarre point of view.

The other thing that has to be said is that if one looks at who is actually carrying out the research, if one looks at the consultancy program for 1986-87 in the annual report of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region, one finds that there is consultancy work being undertaken by the Chisholm Institute of Technology, the University of New England, the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory, the CSIRO Division of Land and Water Resources, and the University of Wollongong.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good university.

—Yes, and an excellent member too. Consultancy work is also being done by ANSTO, the Northern Territory Museum of Arts and Sciences, the University of Sydney, the CSIRO's Division of Soils, and the Australian National University. So the research is being done. Their role is largely a co-ordinating one but the research work being done, to use the ghastly cliche, is all region specific. In other words, it is done on the site and people come in from outside. Some criticisms have been raised, not as vociferously in this debate as in the debate exactly 12 months ago along the same lines, of the fact that about a third of the personnel are in Sydney. These always sounds like awkward fractions but 41.5 of the staff are in Jabiru and 26.2 of the staff are in Sydney. That always suggests that they share a digit or a forearm or something.
—The rest are travelling in between.

—Yes, something like that. Obviously if one thinks of executive work such as policy co-ordination and information, getting material out, printing, computer modelling, computer support, mathematical modelling and things such as that, I do not think it is too difficult to see how one can get a figure of 26 staff outside the area. The overwhelming bulk of the research capability is on the spot. We can see no cogent reason why the role of the OSS should be changed, nor change the arrangements by which the OSS is ultimately responsible to the national Parliament. Having said that, that is not to say that it will go on like this forever. It depends on the circumstances. I put it to the House that the case has not been adequately put. The result is that the Government rejects the amendment which has been moved to the motion for the second reading and urges support for the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the legislation relates to the ability to make charges for export inspection services. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 will allow effective recovery of the costs of inspection services at establishments not registered for the preparation of food and primary products for export. The Bill also makes other amendments that are consequential to the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill to which I have previously referred.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills basically relate to new export inspection charges imposed by this Government by way of export control orders relative to the horticultural industry and sections of the grain industry for their exports commencing on 1 January this year. The Bills provide some ability to assist in the collection of those charges or for the inspection services that are to be undertaken in a better and more flexible way than would otherwise be the case.

The horticultural industry and sections of the grain industry which have been affected by these export inspection charges are violently opposed to the whole procedure of the Government in relation to the issues that we are debating. It imposes dramatically increased costs on their exports at a time when the Government is supposedly wanting all the exports that it can get. Australia desperately needs them. Today we heard that we have run another monthly trade deficit of over $700m. In general detail that is how those bulk figures, which I cited earlier, are made up. Many people in the industry have views on what that means in actual cost per hour and in total cost. For example, I have received today a fax from the Sydney Market Authority which states in part:

Some of the major fruit and vegetable exporters report that their combined time and phytosanitary charges equate to $100 plus per hour. At 50 per cent recovery this means that the total cost is in excess of $200 per hour.

That contrasts with the calculated figure of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy of about $28 per hour total cost when one includes both a direct and indirect cost of inspection. I commend the Department-in spite of other criticism that will be made of it during my comments-for providing to the industry, to me and to others detailed calculations of those costs. As I said, this opposition has come from every export group including apples and pears, citrus and nursery products.
