I will not greatly delay the House with my contribution, especially because I know that there is quite a list of Opposition speakers on this legislation. As an aside, it always surprises me that the Opposition constantly harangues this Government about cost recovery and about how we have got to have the user pay principle, but criticises the Government immediately it brings in some of the user pay principles.

As has been said, these Bills amend the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985 to provide greater flexibility for the recovery of costs incurred in providing export inspection services. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 imposes a charge on the provision of an export inspection service at an establishment which is registered for the preparation of food and primary produce for export. Increasingly, inspection services are provided at places that are not registered. The Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill will allow effective recovery of the costs of these external export inspection services, without imposing unnecessary registration requirements upon the exporter. External export inspection services would normally be performed to assist the exporter by providing certificates required by the importing country, rather than to ensure compliance with Australian export controls.

The principal purpose of the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill is to enable charges to be imposed in relation to the export inspection of fruit, vegetables, live animals and animal reproductive material. This will allow the Government to use the most effective legislative means to recoup inspection costs. But, as the honourable member for Murray has indicated, these Bills apply very much to horticultural products. Export inspection and certification provides clear commercial benefit to agricultural exporters by ensuring that their products have access to overseas markets.

In view of the commercial benefit, but recognising the benefit to the community from the generation of export income, the Government requires industry to meet 50 per cent of the cost of providing the export inspection service. This policy has applied for a number of years to the inspection of all agricultural products, except horticultural products. It is really bringing horticultural products into line with other agricultural products. With substantial progress now being made in the development of uniform inspection procedures for horticultural products, it is appropriate that this industry begin to meet its share of inspection costs.

I listened to what the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia said; namely, that a lot of the industry is violently opposed to what is proposed. It has always been my experience, since I have been in Parliament, that immediately a cost is put upon anyone or any product there is opposition. The violence of that opposition varies, but I have yet to see the day when any government of any political persuasion imposes a cost on someone and there is no opposition to it. He also made a lot of the point that the industry had not been consulted. My information is that there has been extensive consultation with the industry. Indeed, it has been aware of the likelihood of inspection charges for about four years. The intention to introduce inspection charges on 1 January 1988 was announced as part of the Budget in September 1987. Industry was consulted during the development of the inspection procedures, which was a precondition to the introduction of inspection charges. It is true, as the honourable member for Murray has said, that there is to be a review of the charges, and the Minister has given that undertaking.

I have indicated that I support the legislation and reject the amendment. Having said that, I do have some worries about the legislation, especially as it applies to the horticultural industry. Returns in, for instance, the cut flower industry are not great. It is a growing export industry that I believe we, as a government, should support. I worry that the inspection fees could have an impact in particular on the cut flowers export industry. This could come about because cut flowers are very perishable. They must be exported in small consignments at close frequency-say, three times a week-and because the growing areas need to be clustered around the fringes of metropolitan areas, where the international airports are located--

TALK.START.PARA: —Bunched rather than clustered.

—Bunched together, yes. Because of that there is rarely a cohesive growing area where all the products can be inspected together. Separate bits of a consignment are often consolidated at the airport. I believe that the effect of these two related factors makes for multiple inspections, and if these are charged for at some of the rates proposed the resultant cost could, I believe, do damage to what is a fledgling export industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I represent a group of people from the Robertson area who export proteas, and there is a growing demand for these flowers in the Japanese market. Those people have put to me that they are worried about the cost of this inspection fee to their industry. They have suggested that perhaps the phytosanitary certificate could be paid for all exports, but the charges for on-site attendance could be regarded as a normal agricultural extension role, especially for the small packing sheds. They have argued that they should be waived below a certain threshold, perhaps $1,000. I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to consider this, if not in relation to this legislation, then certainly when the fees are being looked at.

Another problem that has been brought to my attention by one of my constituents is the cost of the inspection and the issue of the certificates for sending samples abroad. A constituent of mine has built up a very successful business over the last three years exporting kentia palms. By his hard work and diligence he has built up a very important and profitable export business to the United States of America. He has now expanded that business to Europe and he is about to enter the Asian market. Having recently been in Asia, I believe that there is a market for these kentia palms there. I know that the business expertise that he has built up will mean a very good and profitable export business which will earn valuable export dollars for Australia. He has put to me that he would have to pay these costs just to have his samples inspected and to receive the certificate. As anyone in business knows, samples are a cost that has to be outlaid and for which one cannot expect to get a recovery. He is worried that if these costs are imposed he will not be able to afford to send his samples overseas.

I ask the Minister to consider carefully waiving these costs for people sending horticultural samples abroad, because this is a very important and growing market for Australia. It is like the cut flower market. I believe that we can break into especially the Asian market, and that will bring valuable export dollars to Australia. I support the Government's stand on cost recovery and on the user pays principle. But I think that sometimes we have to balance this delicately and ask ourselves whether we are being wise in the short term but foolish in the long term. I am sure that the Minister will either address this in his summing up or look very carefully at it during the review. As I said, I do believe that valuable export dollars can be earned and I would not like us to do anything rash that may jeopardise that. I have also said that I know that the Minister will give this consideration, because he has no intention of crippling a small but important and growing export trade for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —A sunrise industry.

—A sunrise industry, indeed a bunch of sunrise industries, and we must do nothing to hinder their growth and blossoming into even more important industries. I said that I would not delay the House for very long. I know that my colleague shares some of my concerns because we have briefly discussed this. I commend the Bills to the House and I oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House for the opportunity to participate in this debate and to follow my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis). I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), which I have already seconded, and I wish to make an observation or two about the comments made by the honourable member for Throsby. It seems to me that he has found himself in a rather vexed position. I am not one who believes in star signs. I tend, if anything, to follow them merely to get something of a giggle. I do not know under which star sign the honourable member for Throsby was born, but I would not be surprised if he were a Gemini, because in this afternoon's debate he is clearly suffering from something of a split personality. The electors of Throsby ought to know that, while their member of parliament claims to support the legislation and reject the amendment, a perusal of Hansard will reveal that he has gone a long way towards supporting the amendment and that he sympathises with this side of the House.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Throsby quite rightly said that this is an important piece of legislation and I have no doubt that he was sincere in so stating, but a glance at the speakers lists would leave anyone who is listening to this debate wondering precisely how important the Government feels this legislation is. While the honourable member for Throsby, speaking from the Government benches, was supposedly speaking in support of the legislation, a perusal of Hansard will reveal that he has found himself in a rather vexed position. I now turn to the only other speaker on the Government side, the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), who will follow me. I think I might be forgiven for asking, without any intention of being uncharitable, just what particular rural interest the honourable member for Kingston has and why it is that the only people on the Government side speaking in support of this legislation are the honourable member for Throsby, who seems to be in a rather difficult position, and the honourable member for Kingston, who, so far as I am aware, has no rural involvement at all.

By contrast, I rise in this debate as one who has long been involved in the importance of both quarantine and inspection in one form or another. I spent most of my primary production life in the Riverland area of South Australia, the one area of the nation that claims proudly to be fruit fly free. No-one will stress to me the importance of quarantine. There is no doubt that rigid standards are required if we are to maintain our reputation in any of our export markets. I am very much aware of how the level of inspection that was provided on road blocks in the fruit fly area kept the Riverland of South Australia fruit fly free. The legislation before the House today will enable the inspection of horticultural crops that are about to be exported to maintain the sort of standard that our export markets demand. I suggest that we need to see as much diligence and enthusiasm from the Government in enforcing quarantine restrictions on imports as we currently have for export crops.

Anyone in this House representing apple and pear producers, as some members on this side of the House do, would be aware of the concern of the apple and pear producers about the current level of inspection of imports and the threat of fire blight, for example, from New Zealand crops. I have been besieged, as have other members of the House, by members of the Australian Nurserymen's Association Ltd, who are concerned that we be as diligent about the inspection of imports as this legislation is about the inspection of exports in order to protect our nursery crops, our floricultural crops and our horticultural crops from the viruses that may well be contained in plants brought into Australia which are not necessarily evident when those plants first land on our shores.

There is in this legislation a demand that our export markets be serviced with quality products, and that demand is echoed and supported around the chamber. The real concern expressed by the Opposition and, if I may be repetitious, by the honourable member for Throsby, is about the present fee structure and the fact that there has been no consultation and that the fee applies regardless of how large the export order happens to be. The legislation before the House affects principally, but by no means exclusively, horticultural crops. This legislation provides the facility for the export inspection of crops about to be exported from non-registered premises. The fact that the legislation gives the inspector the opportunity to enter non-registered premises provides the focus on horticultural crops.

Our major export products-wheat, sheep, meat and wool-have principally been exported from what have historically been registered premises. In the horticultural area we have a number of smaller crops such as orchids, cut flowers, plants and even fruit that have been packed in non-registered packing houses, and this legislation allows the charging of a fee for the inspection of that export preparation in non-registered premises. A number of packing houses have been registered under various Acts, some of them State and some Federal. Fruit has been prepared in these houses, the export inspectors have been there and a fee has been charged for that export inspection. As the honourable member for Throsby says, with the growth in the floricultural and cut flower areas, there have been a number of small packages prepared for export, and this legislation allows the consignment to be inspected on site. This legislation also allows a fee to be charged for the export inspection that that Department of Primary Industries and Energy inspector then undertakes.

No-one is quibbling about the application of some fee for export inspection. No-one, to restate my case, is quibbling about the fact that there must be export inspection in order to maintain Australia's reputation overseas. The Opposition's concern and the concern expressed by some honourable members opposite is that there has been too little consultation with industry and no flexibility in the application of this legislation. So a horticultural crop that may be valued at $100 will attract exactly the same fee for inspection as a container load of horticultural crops valued at $100m.

Today in the House we had a great illustration of the importance of horticultural exports to the national economy. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) came into the House, as is his wont, and regaled us all with the great job he saw the Government doing because it happens that our balance of payments deficit will fall to something like half a billion dollars a month instead of over $1 billion a month. I find it difficult to know why as a member of the Opposition I am supposed to rejoice at a deficit of $11 billion per annum, but that was the premise put to me by Treasurer Keating. What he failed to say, and what honourable members in Opposition representing rural industries will keep reminding him of day in and day out, is that the improvement in our balance of payments deficit has largely been reflected in the way in which our primary industries, principally wool, have made it possible for us to earn additional income overseas. I refer the House to a recent article in the Australian by Julian Cribb, who wrote:
The wool industry, riding on the crest of a continuing market surge, is set to break the $4 billion export barrier in 1987-88.
Total shorn wool production in the coming year has been estimated at 805 million kilograms, the second largest clip in Australian history.
Much has been made of our wool exports, but I ask the House to consider that even the beleaguered grain industry is performing well. Julian Cribb went on to say:

Another industry performing well in the face of ferocious world competition is wheat. The Australian Wheat Board has announced that, barring disputes, wheat shipments in the 12 months ended September will be 15.6 million tonnes.
This is only slightly less than the record 16 million tonnes shipped the previous year . . .

Much of the recovery Treasurer Keating has alluded to has come from existing rural industries and, furthermore, the opportunities for further national recovery will come from the opportunities that horticultural crops currently offer to the Australian economy. One industry affected by the legislation before the House but which promises enormous growth is the floricultural industry. Currently we are exporting $10m worth of flowers a year into a global market estimated at $16 billion. There is a chance, in spite of the legislation before the House, for a further rural industry to take steps to address the present balance of payments deficit that continues to haunt the Treasurer.

The Australian newspaper of 18 February1988 refers to the South Australian Director of the Department of State Development, Mr Keith Smith, as having said that horticultural exports to the Asian region, particularly Singapore, have been growing steadily during the past three years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially in South Australia.
—As the honourable member for Curtin points out, especially in South Australia. The article went on:

SPEECH.PARA: The increase began when Adelaide's international terminal was opened, allowing perishable fruit and vegetables to be sent directly to overseas destinations.
`Fruit can be picked in the cool of the morning, packed and sent out on the afternoon plane to be over there in time for the opening of the markets next morning,' Mr Smith said.
Produce exported from South Australia includes rockmelon, cauliflower, lettuce, apricots, cherries, celery and broccoli.

The honourable member for Kingston will be anxious also to identify with the opportunities South Australia has to capitalise principally on horticultural exports. I could go on listing the number of other opportunities in the Hong Kong market, and in the United Kingdom, for example, where, in spite of the European Economic Community, the sale of dried sultanas has increased from 2,000 tonnes in 1982 to 17,000 tonnes last year. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) will want to stress to the House what is happening to nurseries, and to wild flower exports from Western Australia, and what that is doing further to redress our balance of payments deficit, and the opportunities that horticulture provides in turning around Australia's economic fortunes.

The difficulty is that we have before the House this afternoon a piece of legislation one would think was specifically designed to stunt the horticultural exporters in their endeavours to find new markets. Everyone must be aware that in most of our horticultural markets, indeed in most of our rural markets overseas, the margins are still very small. Only the falling Australian dollar has given the opportunity for the horticultural industry to move into new export markets. Yet we have before the House legislation that has not been taken to the horticultural industry and which has not been discussed with it. This means the industry will face a further cost burden in opening up further export markets. Again I stress that the Opposition is not opposed to the concept. It shares with the honourable member for Throsby a good deal of concern about inflexibility and lack of consulta- tion that has occurred in this legislation.

I wish to illustrate my point by referring to two letters, one from the Northern Victoria Fruitgrowers Association Ltd which reports on a meeting-this was referred to by the honourable member for Murray-of the major export fruit packing establishments. The letter stated:

This meeting rejects the proposal to implement 50 per cent inspection charges from 1st January 1988 because of the lack of consultation, allocation of unfair charges and lack of the practicability of implementation.
The other letter, from Wondabah Orchids Pty Ltd of Carlingford, stated:
When this Fee for Inspection was decided upon there had not been any discussion with anyone in this particular industry . . .

That letter is signed by one of the staff for Mr Robert Giles, the managing director. There has been no consultation with the orchid industry, one of the industries which may be affected most because it is one industry where a consignment could well be valued at anything from $100 to $100m, who knows what, in orchid values. The lack of consultation is the thing that the Opposition has found most frustrating in its endeavour to give some credibility to the legislation before the House.

It would be sufficient if the only concern we had was the concern expressed by horticultural industries, but this legislation does not affect just the horticultural industry. It affects all new primary production exporting industries that have not been covered by some form of inspection fee for service. I refer to a letter I had handed to me by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), one of whose constituents wrote to him saying:
Exporters are very unhappy about the enclosed information. As a reg. packing house with DPI we are not happy. No one from DPI or Dep Ag consulted us about it.

That constituent is Ambiack Pty Ltd from Warracknabeal, and the product that company is exporting is not floricultural or horticultural. That company is a pea and grain exporter. It is affected not only by the level of charges in the legislation but by the fact that there was no consultation, no opportunity for the company to put a point of view to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) or to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

Another area directly affected by the legislation and so far not referred to in this debate is animal reproductive exports. I was fascinated to discover that among the areas covered by this Bill is the potential to export animal reproductive material. At the heart of my electorate is the Collinsville merino stud. As recently as last week Mr Neil Garnett, the principal of Collinsville, announced his intention to provide some sort of export industry to New Zealand and give New Zealand the opportunity to share some of the benefits of the remarkable Collinsville merinos.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an embryo exporting industry.

—As the honourable member for Murray points out, that is an embryo exporting industry. No doubt that too will be affected by the legislation before the House. I have no doubt that Mr Garnett has not been approached by anyone from the Department, much less the Minister's office, to see what this particular burden will do to this fledgling industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The concern of the Opposition is that the people it represents are not being consulted. These people do not expect simply to be allowed to export willy nilly. They welcome the concept of some sort of export inspection. More than that, they are prepared to accept a fair level of what ought to be their participation in the cost recovery, but they resent that with a dictatorial attitude the Government has come to them and said, `This is what you will pay'. There has been no level of consultation and no opportunity for them to point out to the Government what may well be inequities in the legislation before the House.

Most of all, people in the industry are just a shade cynical about the role of departmental inspectors. Most of them have seen these inspectors working in registered premises. They know that the inspectors will be gone at 5 o'clock whether the export parcel is ready or not. If inspectors are asked to stay on later there will be double time and all sorts of other inflexibilities. The exporters work under arrangements that provide a good deal of give and take between employers and employees. They see this legislation as breaking down that level of give and take and the sort of family atmosphere that they have managed to create in their own export premises. Their cynicism is understandable, particularly as they have seen no consultation at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to participate in this debate, to which there have been some useful contributions, and to follow the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). I might begin by enlightening the honourable member for Wakefield about the industries I have in my electorate that are affected by this legislation. In my electorate I have some state of the art orchid growers and exporters, growers of plants and growers of cut flowers. In my view they are very much in the mould of the industries we ought to be encouraging to attack the problems we now suffer with our balance of payments. I would like particularly to commend my colleague the honourable member for Throsby on what I thought was a very intelligent and well-reasoned address to this House, much of which applies to my own electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to support the Bills and to oppose the amendment moved by the Opposition for reasons that I will now outline. The two Bills we are considering, the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill, raise funds to offset the cost of inspecting goods for export in line with the Government's policy of recovering 50 per cent of the cost of providing export inspection services. This will enable the export inspection service to continue to match the growing demands for its invaluable and essential services as a guarantor of the quality of Australian exports of primary product and at the lowest possible cost. Moreover, it will enable the export inspection service to do so in the best possible manner by striking a balance between the need to provide assistance to emergent exporters by providing low cost inspection services, and, on the other hand, the need for both exporters and the inspection service to pay heed to the true cost of providing such services. That, I might add, is a very important consideration if we are to avoid creating mendicant and artificial export industries that are forever dependent on subsidies, industries of a kind with which we have been much too familiar in Australia in the past.

In this sense these two Bills fit well into the Government's strategy of rebuilding Australia's economy so that we can become internationally competitive and continue to be so in areas where we are already competitive. Like our opponents when they were in government, we are not prepared to sit back and wait for the world to come to us. We realise that in an increasingly complex world economy we cannot afford to rely on our abundant natural resources alone. We must be prepared to use our minds, to work harder, to work better, to work smarter, to build a reputation for our processed value added exports as well as our raw materials exports. That is the export philosophy of this Government and we are doing something about that philosophy.

Throughout the Government's first five years we have worked hard to create both a domestic and international climate that is suitable for increasing Australia's exports. What is more, this has been done in the face of a deterioration in world trade brought on at first by increasing protectionism overseas and now, allied with that, a tendency to look for bilateral solutions that owe nothing to a philosophy of free trade. At home we have been actively promoting outward-looking, export-minded, and internationally competitive manufacturers and service industries through the efforts of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and others. These efforts have brought about a boom in tourism to the point where we are expecting almost two million overseas visitors this year, and a rise in merchandise exports to the point where they brought $3.5 billion in overseas earnings last month alone.

Through initiatives such as the Button plan for the motor vehicle industry, the steel plan, and the heavy industry packages unions and businesses have been encouraged to shrug off protection at a pace that gives them time to restructure rather than condemned to some kind of supply side slaughterhouse. As a result, we have firms such as Comeng exporting trams to Hong Kong, and Mitsubishi's Lonsdale engine plant, in my own electorate, exporting engines around the world. An even bigger employer in my electorate is the firm Sola Optical, which is easily the largest manufacturer in Australia of plastic spectacles lenses. It has some nine subsidiary plants around the world and it is likely to become the biggest manufacturer in this extremely competitive field. In my electorate this company does its own main value-added work and carries out its own research and development. If there were more companies like it, we would not have a current account problem.

This same philosophy has encouraged the Holden's engine company to get its act together so that it has become the largest manufacturing exporter in this country. Recently it exported its one millionth family two engine to overseas customers. The Government's efforts to restore our international competitiveness have been such that in December we recorded a balance of trade surplus of $518m. February's figures show that that trend is continuing and improving. However, we now recognise there is much more to be done. To this end the Hawke Government has put in place a range of programs to ensure that exports will continue to grow and diversify. In our last term the present Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), created the Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, to advise and assist exporters. Also the Minister launched a two-year national export drive campaign. The video cassette that the Minister put together to encourage exporters, which I showed to a number of potential exporters in my electorate recently, is a first-rate demonstration of that commitment.

The Government also has overhauled the export market development scheme. Although it is fair to say that there are still a few bugs in the new scheme that deserve to be ironed out, the overhauling of the scheme has attempted to target assistance more directly to those actually performing in the export field as distinct from those who show no particular result for their efforts. A further aspect of the Government's efforts is the amalgamation of the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Trade, which will unite trade and foreign policy in a way that recognises the importance of international policy to our economic future. As a part of that amalgamation a special trade lobbyist has been appointed in Washington to promote Australian trade and economic interests, particularly on Capitol Hill among congressmen and senators. Recently, I had the opportunity to speak with Mr McCarthy when he was in Australia and I believe the enterprise is proceeding well. I mention also the convening of the Cairns group of free traders, which is campaigning extensively at international meetings for more open access to non-subsidised agricultural products, particularly in the United States and European markets.

We realise, however, that if we are to sustain the competitiveness we have nurtured, we cannot afford to rely just on shifts in the value of the dollar or the strength of salesmanship. Worst of all, if we were to retreat into some sort of cloud-cuckoo-land of McEwenism, that would be hypocritical and stupid. With the help of the trade union movement particularly the Government has embarked upon a program to improve the quality of our work force by revitalising our education and training systems and restructuring our industrial relations system. These changes will make us desirably more flexible and, ultimately, much more responsive to changing technology and economic circumstances. The reduction of work classifications in industries such as the metal industry is a step in that direction. Nor is the public sector being neglected, as the recent decision by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to direct the Industries Assistance Commission to review the impact of government services and charges on our economy demonstrates. Just as changes are being made as a result of these two Bills, this review will make the public sector more mindful of how it fits into our export economy. It is against that background that I wish to comment specifically along the lines of what my colleague the honourable member for Throsby said about particular provisions of the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill. There are in my electorate two companies that deserve special mention: Adelaide Orchids Pty Ltd and Valley Orchids. Their products are absolute state of the art so far as this industry is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should bring some orchids in here some time and let us see them.

—Perhaps I will do that because they are absolutely beautiful. Those members of the House who have not visited an up-to-date orchid growing establishment recently should do so; I believe they would find it well worth their while. As much as anything, this is a high tech industry. Once the grower has succeeded in breeding a prize winning or new orchid, the plant is cloned and tissue cultured so that from the one new orchid a great number of plants can be produced for export. By and large these exporters have a pattern of exports for which these particular charges are somewhat discriminatory. For example, exporters of Western Australian wild flowers export large volumes all at once. Traditionally, the orchid grower makes large numbers of small value shipments, yet each of those shipments has to be inspected, usually on site.

SPEECH.PARA: The charges which are proposed, $28 for the first half-hour and $11 for each half-hour thereafter, plus $20 per certificate and a $5 inspection fee, mean that growers may well be up for a minimum of $53 per inspection of one small parcel of export-directed shipments which might, for example, be worth only $200 altogether. I have seen figures which suggest that the average value of orchid exports from one of the growers in my electorate is less than $700, so the charge really is quite a considerable proportion of the value of the shipment.

We need to remember that in all cases, at least so far as orchid exports are concerned, the growers themselves complete the certificate which is required to accompany the export. In all cases it is they who ensure that the goods meet world standards. It would be quite senseless commercially for them not to do so because they would cut themselves off from the very markets they are trying to sell into. It is also fair to say that in many cases the inspectors have been trained by the growers, who know far more about the industry and the things to look for than does the best inspector. I do not mean to be disrespectful to the inspectors but the orchid grower has lived with his product, knows it better than anybody else and knows what needs to be looked for.

The suggestion I would like to put forward in this debate is that instead of a per shipment inspection, which as I have said is discriminatory against growers with the pattern of exports I have spoken about, there be something of the order of an annual registration system. This has been introduced successfully by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species under its cost recovery program. That cost recovery is carried out by issuing a six monthly licence for which the grower pays a fee. However, it was originally proposed that there be a per shipment inspection. An annual registration system would also remove a burden from the inspection service, since current demands for inspections tend to be erratic. I think it was the honourable member for Throsby who pointed out that these facilities are often established some distance from the main cities. That requires inspectors to travel a long distance and results in a disproportionate drain on the staff of the inspection service.

The differing requirements of the very many countries to which exporters send flowers, in particular, are another aspect. I would like to echo the remarks of the honourable member for Wakefield about the value to Australia of the floricultural industry. He said that exports at the moment are running at around $100m. I think it is somewhat more than that. I was recently in Japan-I had better add, at the expense of the Japanese Government and not the Australian taxpayer-and while I was there I took the opportunity to look into the market for flowers, both cut flowers and potted blooms. I found the size of the market that exists there to be absolutely staggering.

We are well placed to enter that market in a bigger way-we are already in it in a certain way-because of the quality of the product that is produced, at least in my electorate and I guess in the rest of Australia as well. The flower market has also been identified by Austrade as worthy of continued attention in Japan. It is one of only a few such areas that Austrade proposes to devote special attention to in the next year or two. I reinforced those impressions gained by talking to Australian officials in Japan by visiting the Ministry of Agriculture there and speaking at great length with Japanese officials who encouraged me in my belief that this is an extraordinary and very lucrative market and one in which we are well placed to get into, provided we have the quality and expertise, which we do, and provided no undue difficulties are put in the way of exporters who intend to attack that market.

There are in my electorate orchid growers who are prepared to undertake considerable capital investment to do better in this market, but it would be helpful if the current regime of inspection charges were changed to something a little more rational. Having dealt with the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) and his predecessor over several months about the export charge regime, I have been very encouraged to have from him an undertaking that after several months it will be possible to look again at the export charges regime. I believe my colleague the honourable member for Throsby would agree with me that we need some sort of a system which, while not negating the principle of this legislation, which I support, would relate the cost recovery program more clearly to the value of the exports rather than to the number of shipments. Some periodic licence system which would be pretty well self-regulating, because the growers have a very great interest in seeing that they play the game, would be the way to go. I support the Bill and oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us apparently harmless legislation to amend the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Act 1985 and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Act 1985. The Government would have us believe that these amending Bills have only a minor financial impact upon the costs to the industry and that charges simply will replace the cost recovery measures that currently apply. It may well be that, in the insulated bureaucratic environment from which these amendments grew, they are simple measures and the impact minor. In reality, Australia's horticultural exporters and producers operate in a harsh and competitive environment. Any government imposition has a major impact on the industry. Unfortunately, the Government would not know the impact of these Bills because the people most affected, the producers and exporters, have not been consulted.

SPEECH.PARA: The net effect of this legislation will be to penalise an industry that has taken up the challenge of seeking out and servicing the highly competitive fresh fruit, vegetable and flower markets of the world-and has done it very successfully. The horticultural sector is already doing what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) begged of other primary industries when he addressed the Committee for Economic Development of Australia in Melbourne on 28 January. He said:

The fall in world commodity prices and the demand for primary products, compounded by traditional weakness in our internal economy, have highlighted the importance of improving the efficiency and competitiveness of our primary industries.
At the same time, we need to achieve greater export returns and reduce our dependency on overseas capital, and reduce our current account deficit.
To succeed we must develop a more efficient, competitive and innovative export sector.

What the Minister did not say in his speech but embodied in this legislation is that, while the industry is doing something about our trade imbalances, the Government will take more than it is entitled to for providing an export inspection service.

While we are asked to believe that the inspection charge will have only a minor impact on the Treasury coffers-in the Government's estimate about $1.8m-the Minister was so keen to get his hands on the money that he issued an order last December for the fees to be collected. As a result of the Minister's indecent haste, since 1 January exporters of fresh fruit and vegetables and non-prescribed horticultural products have been required to pay the inequitable and unfair inspection fees. The industry is confused and angry at the Government's so-called minor financial impact that will amount to some $4m annually Australia-wide. In my own State's case, it will represent an additional cost of some $1.5m and, on our export sales in Western Australia, that will amount to a 3 per cent increase. Those increases cannot be collected from the purchasers-they have to be passed to the producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was speaking on the impact of these Bills on the Government's expenditure estimates. A classic example of the Government's bungled attempts to estimate the cost of programs such as those foreshadowed in this legislation could well be the estimates given for the revenue to be raised from the fringe benefits tax. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his 1986-87 estimates indicated that we would raise $325m from this tax, and in fact we raised $535m. An additional $121m was raised from crude oil, and pay as you earn tax receipts were up by $100m.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills do not show us the ludicrous inequities in the fee schedule. Some exporters will be severely disadvantaged by the burden of inspection fees they have not previously had to pay unless overtime was involved. A Western Australian flower exporter will struggle to stay competitive in a knife-edged competitive world market because the change will cost him, generally, $20,000 extra per year. Make no mistake, our market share will gladly and rapidly be taken up by countries such as Taiwan, Holland and South Africa. The charges will cost a medium size fruit and vegetable exporter in Western Australia some $40,000 and, in Queensland, $50,000 to $60,000. As an example of the inequities, an apple exporter sending one aircraft container load overseas must pay $5 to have it inspected and to have a phytosanitary health certificate issued-that is, 89c a carton-but the exporter's commission is generally only around 80c. Clearly the extra cost must be passed on to the producer. The value of a carton of apples is around $12, not including freight costs. The extra 89c raises the cost to the buyer by some 7.4 per cent.

Companies wishing to break into the new flower markets are generally required to send potential buyers small shipments of sample seeds. The cost of a health certificate and the inspection of a package of sample seeds is some $48, but the seeds would not be worth more than $20 or $30. The new charging system costs low value low volume exporters proportionately more than others in the industry. If it costs $48 to inspect a 15-tonne container of carrots and issue one certificate, that charge can be absorbed more readily than in the case of a flower exporter loading three containers into an aircraft. In addition to the $28 inspection fee, each container requires a health certificate, at a cost of $20 each. Profit margins in the floriculture industry are too lean to absorb such charges.

Unfortunately with these charges it is not a two-way street. Under the fee schedule the exporter and producer are at the mercy of the inspector. They have no control over the costs imposed regardless of the level of efficiency of the service. We are talking about an industry that has been an international success story for Australia. Australian exports of fruit and vegetables have increased by some 168 per cent since 1981-82. In 1986-87 Western Australia's fruit and vegetable exports were worth some $35.8m, a rise of some 91 per cent over the same period. Flower exports have been a real success story, with a growth of some 204 per cent over the last five years. In all respects the horticultural industry is doing what the Government continually bleats about. Senator Peter Walsh, in his address in January to the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, said:
We must have great efforts towards improved domestic productivity and improved international competitiveness.
Treasurer Keating said to a meeting of the Economic Planning Advisory Council on 19 February:
The EPAC scenario envisages a rate of economic growth just sufficient to maintain the present level of unemployment.
Even this outcome depends on a continuation of strong export growth and continued responsiveness to the domestic economy.

Yet the Government rewards efficiency and achievement with arrogance. It failed to consult the Western Australian horticultural industry on this matter. The first advice of the Government's intentions was a media release last December by the former Minister for Resources, the Minister for Transport and Communications Support (Mr Peter Morris). Letters from the industry have not even been acknowledged. I have letters from the industry to that Minister and Minister Kerin in regard to these charges. To date the Ministers have not even had the courtesy to acknowledge or answer the letters.

The industry clearly deserves a better deal. Coalition policy is to meet 100 per cent of the cost of export inspection charges because it is in the national interest that we have our exports facilitated. At the very least, the Government should defer the charges until a fairer system can be devised and until the revenue estimates can be corrected to enable a lower schedule of charges to be set.

Earlier tonight some honourable members from the Government spoke on this matter. The honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) spoke of methods he envisaged for charging the industry more fairly. The honourable member went on to say that he thought there would probably be inequities in the system, that different industries would have to pay proportionately too much, and that there might well need to be an annual fee. Quite clearly, what we are asking for in the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the National Party and shadow Minister is that a more equitable and accountable system of charges and procedures be established. The problem has been that the industry has not been consulted. The industry has had this position lumped on it with little or no opportunity to respond to it and it has had no time to look at passing on the costs or absorbing them. Our amendment asks simply that the charges be deferred until such time as the industry can be fully consulted and a fairer method of charging worked out. In this respect I support the amendment put forward and ask members on the Government side, if they are fair dinkum, also to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interesting thing about this debate is that speakers from both sides of the House have spoken about the potential of the markets we have for horticulture. I totally agree with this and it is principally the reason why I wish to speak in this debate. Undoubtedly Australia is on the launching pad so far as the future of horticultural exports is concerned. I and I am sure the members of the Party to which I belong have great faith in the future of agriculture in Australia. We solidly believe that over a period, considering the economy of this nation, basically we must come back to the production of agriculture and the sale of goods we have made to get the Australian economy back on line. We are not shortsighted with respect to other production sources within Australia, particularly in the manufacturing field, which covers many types of product. However, I want to emphasise that Australia is basically a country dependent upon the soil, and we have a great responsibility as the years progress to produce the type of food that the rest of the world is looking to consume. We will not be able to satisfy the needs of countries such as Ethiopia and others around the world whose people, we are told, are starving. But we should be in a position to be able to supply those countries which can buy goods from us.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills that are before us-the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill 1988 and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1988-have implications regarding the matters that I have just spoken about. They may appear to have rather small consequences, but that is not the case when one considers the effect that they may have on inducing Australian farmers to produce those goods that we expect them to produce, to meet the expectations of trade. It certainly affects them so far as the cost of production on the farm is concerned.

If we look at the retail price of any horticultural or primary products that we sell in Australia, we will see that what the farmer receives is very often well below 50 per cent of the product's shelf price. Undoubtedly, if we look at the export price, the price received by the farmers would possibly be well below 50 per cent. So the farmer is concerned that those proportions do not grow too far apart. In other words, the producer should receive a reasonable price, having regard to the retail price of the product. I know that farmers in Australia have no control over what Japan, or any other country to which we sell, will charge for the product on their domestic markets; nor should we have. We should not look at that aspect. That is a matter for the countries concerned. They impose import duties so far as our exporters are concerned. We are concerned about the price that will be received by farmers in Australia.

In the last couple of days I have read some articles that have been written in this country over the last year or so, particularly since the start of Austrade. From what I have read, and from what I have learnt from a few exporters in my electorate, Austrade appears to be doing a pretty good job. I congratulate it, particularly so far as horticulture is concerned, because it has seen the opportunity to start new industries that are conducive to the type of soil and climates that occur in Australia. I represent an electorate on the New South Wales coast which is basically rural and tourist based. However, many of the farms are being subdivided. There has been some inducement for the owners of farms that were previously dairy farms or used for grazing purposes to subdivide the properties. Many of these smaller acreages are now being turned over to small crops.

I am speaking in the debate tonight because the two Bills before the House to some degree affect those people. Many more of these types of people will set up properties to produce such crops in Australia. The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), who is seated in front of me, represents an area which has some of the choicest irrigative land in Australia. If the markets can be found, there is a tremendous opportunity to produce such goods for processing in Australia and for export. I have a lot of citrus growers in my electorate. Over recent years these people have been terribly disturbed because they have not been able to find a market for their goods. There are opportunities for Australian farmers-this can be seen by looking at Queensland, which produces about 40 to 43 per cent of our rural exports-to export tropical fruit to Europe. Europe does not produce tropical fruits because they are basically seasonal. We can produce them here, just as we produce oranges to send to Canada and the United States of America at certain times of the year. There is also an opportunity to export up to 20,000 tonnes of oranges a year to Japan.

I spoke earlier about fruit and vegetables being sent to Canada. Vegetables are also sent to New Zealand and the Middle East at certain times of the year. We do not just want to fill a gap in the market at a certain time of the year because that will not be conducive to getting a permanent trade. We are looking to establish a permanent trade in all of the products that we are speaking about. As I said earlier, there are special markets, such as Japan, for oranges. The potential customer for Australia's horticultural market is the Pacific Basin. If we can cultivate the trade by showing that we can package and produce the product that is required by the countries concerned, undoubtedly we will have the opportunity to trade in products that are specifically controlled by the United States, the Canadian markets and by other parts of the world. These people are on our doorstep. They are not too far away for us to market the products. We have to tee up the shipping companies and the airlines. But that is the area in which the potential lies, if we are in a position to make up our minds about meeting the demands.

We must never forget that this country is full of entrepreneurs. It is full of people, particularly within the farming and business communities, who see the opportunity to expand their business. Within my electorate is the Port Stephens rose farm. It is a wonderful tourist attraction. Over 100,000 people a year go to see the rose farm. The property is owned by the Hollidays-Eric and his son, Peter. They are wonderful local people. At present they are exporting cut roses to Hong Kong. I know that you enjoy roses, Madam Speaker. We all do. The Hollidays have the potential to export a tremendous number of roses to different parts of the world. This afternoon I spoke to Peter Holliday. He informed me that they have a potential order of eight tonnes of roses per week to Hong Kong. There are 40 buds to a kilo. Honourable members should think of the multitude of roses that have to be grown to be able to supply eight tonnes per week to any market throughout the world. The important point is that he is sending them there successfully, and he initiated the market himself.

Furthermore, he also manufactures rose petal jam. I can see that you are smiling, Madam Speaker. I would smile also, because every time I leave Taree to go to the south of my electorate, some of the ladies ask me to buy some rose petal jam next time I visit the rose farm. The jam is made on the farm. The Hollidays have sent a trial consignment of jam to Switzerland, Holland, Japan and Great Britain. Undoubtedly, they will find a market in those countries. The owners of the rose farm intend to erect a large greenhouse. They have a commercial kitchen to do the job and, because of their markets, they will employ at least another 50 workers. We can see the potential of that little industry. As I said earlier, there are a lot of these entrepreneurs throughout Australia who will take the opportunity to explore the markets of the Pacific and elsewhere around the world.

I am pleased that I have made an impression tonight. The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) has taken flowers up to Madam Speaker, which I think is nice. They are roses but they were not produced on the rose farm I speak of. If they were they would be red and they would be beautiful. One of these days I will bring you some, Madam Speaker, so you can see them. The Hollidays have found that they can grow the product themselves, using over four million buds a year in the manufacture of their rose petal jam. We are very proud of what these people are doing. They are an illustration of what can be done in regard to the export potential of flowers. This relates also to vegetables and various other products we could find markets for around the world. Austrade sees the potential. It has written many articles identifying where it sees opportunities for these markets. It has encouraged people, to the best of its ability, to invest in and produce these products.

It is nice to see that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) is so interested in what I am saying that he is also presenting Madam Speaker with a rose. I note that it is a red rose. So I know that the House is taking what I am saying on board. The Government has great responsibilities. I appeal to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, who is at the table, to consider some of the problems. The Government should not impose any more duties or costs upon the exporter now. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) spoke about quarantine earlier this evening. I agree with everything that he said. The Government raised the charges from 1 January without consulting people in the horticultural industry. If the Government had consulted them, if it had explained the reasons why it wanted to raise the charges, whether it was to their advantage or otherwise-the Minister must have felt that it was to their advantage-it may have received more support.

The Bills before the House impose extra charges on the producer. A producer would not worry about a reasonable inspection fee. He would be prepared to meet that fee. But he knows that he has to meet the import duties of countries to which he exports. To encourage producers in Australia we want to give the farming industry a hand. If one travels throughout Australia, particularly in the farming areas, one finds that farmers believe that this Government is the highest taxing government they have ever experienced. No matter what legislation the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy or any other Minister brings into this Parliament-whether it concerns finance, Treasury or inspection charges-one can bet one's life that the producer, or somebody within the community, is going to pay extra charges. I instance the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax, the tax upon superannuation and other issues of concern. I know that there has been a reduction in personal taxation for some wage earners, but there has been considerable overkill, a considerable increase, in the amount of tax every Australian is paying. Not only are we paying tax from our payrolls but also we are paying tax on every article we buy. An article in one of yesterday's newspapers tells people the tax we pay on every motor vehicle we buy in Australia. Over half of what we pay for the vehicles we import into Australia goes to the Commonwealth Treasury in the form of tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —More expensive than houses.

—Yes. If every Australian were to sit down and examine the amount of tax he pays on what he eats throughout the day, the clothes he wears, the vehicles he travels in, every commodity he touches, he would be astounded. We do not want to overburden our farm and industry producers who have the ability to balance this country's trade. We do not have a balance of trade. It is in a deficit, worsening month by month. We are buying, not rose petal jam, but plum jam and other jams manufactured in other countries. In every supermarket in Australia are shelves with many items on them manufactured out of Australia. As I said earlier, we are a primary producing country. We should be meeting demand for these products. The argument could be addressed to our iron ore, our coal and the other commodities we are turning out of the soil. If we were to manufacture products from them the balance of trade might be in a different position and we might employ more people.

SPEECH.PARA: I spoke earlier tonight about a person who employs people, the person at the Port Stephens rose farm, the little fellow who has a go, who borrows the money at a high interest rate, who is prepared to go out and work and place himself in active competition with everybody else around him to establish a market and export his product. I take great pride in these people. They are prepared to have a go. They have the pioneering spirit which this country needs in a bicentenary year. Perhaps we do not have that spirit to the extent that we ought to have. No matter what side of politics we represent we have a great responsibility to see that whatever we do we do not tax our people out of existence. We should give them the incentive to work, to raise their families, to produce and export commodities that are competitive with those of other countries. Let no one tell me that Australia cannot do so. I am sure that it can. I have sounded the warning. I support the amendment moved by the shadow Minister. I hope that the Government will take this matter into consideration.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members who have contributed to this debate on the Export Inspection (Service Charge) Amendment Bill and the Export Inspection Charges Collection Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), who was the last speaker for the Opposition, known also as rosy Cowan in various circles, touched on quite a few issues, some not germane to the debate. He touched on jam, among other things and talked about overseas jams coming into Australia. The sugar industry in Australia gets a bit sensitive about that. Jam is about 40 to 45 per cent sugar. We charge our producers of jam the domestic price, which is far different from the world price. That is part of the reason why overseas jam is coming into this country. It is a problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Both parties for a long time have had a policy of 50 per cent cost recovery for export inspection. Part of the reason why this issue has been around for five years with respect to these products is due to the very complexity of it. The 50 per cent cost recovery policy has now been put in place for most commodities. The taxpayers' subsidy for these exporting industries now amounts to over $100m a year. The industry pays the other $100m or so.

In this whole area there are two key philosophical issues, two issues that have been raised in the debate. One is the question of inspection for quality. I think the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) defined export inspection in terms of a need to maintain Australia's reputation overseas. It is Government policy that export inspection occurs solely because of importing countries' requirements. To define export inspection in that way shows a total lack of understanding. I know full well that in the horticultural and floricultural areas there is a constant argument about whether or not inspection should concentrate on quality, but at this stage it seems to me that it will be very difficult to address the question of quality and try to put government certificates onto perishable commodities affirming that a product is of such and such a quality. This is a real problem for perishable products. I do not believe that we really should get into quality inspection. I believe that is best determined in the marketplace or it is best determined by a statutory authority or a private body in terms of taking decisions about some sort of quality assurance.

The other issue of a general nature that was raised in the debate is the question of consultation. I really am a bit disappointed in the Opposition because this tired old tale of a lack of consultation comes up every time as some sort of an excuse or some sort of reason to put forward arguments against what is really the Opposition's true opposition to the legislation; that is, it is a cost on industry and, therefore, it will be unpopular. But we cannot really talk about lack of consultation in this area. The reason I say that I am tired of these old arguments coming up is that I recall very well that, about three years ago when I was told by the Opposition-not the present spokesman on primary industries, but the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt)-that there was no consultation on a dairy matter, I went back through the records and found there had actually been 155 consultations with the dairy industry on this inspection issue. So it will always be used as an excuse.

In this case there has been ongoing consultation with the industry over the past five years but certainly intensively over the past four years. The industry was aware for at least the last four years that there would be charging in this area and the decision to charge was announced in last year's Budget. The industry was consulted in the development of the inspection procedures and the product standards themselves. This was a precondition of the introduction of charging. Industry was also aware that charges were to be imposed for the issue of phytosanitary certificates. The delay in implementing such charges mainly concerned the quantification of the costs of this activity. This involved an enormous amount of consultation, particularly with the State governments which carry out the service basically for the Commonwealth.

The new fees reflect the inspection patterns provided in the standards and procedures which were developed in consultation with industry. I think it is fair to say that I did not take part in each and every one of these consultations, but my departmental officials did ad nauseam; and the correspondence, travelling and work that have been put into this are truly remarkable. That is what the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service is all about. When the orders were made in August 1987, the orders in draft form had already been circulated to industry-in 1985-86. As a consequence of that consultation and circulation, many provisions were deleted, in particular the construction standards for preparation and for the packing establishments. Specific product preparation standards were developed with the particular industry and presentations on the orders were given to various meetings with industries. These presentations were conducted to advise and seek industries' views. This has not come before the Parliament for the five years that my Party has been in office carrying on the policy of the previous Government because of the complexity of the matter.

I will address a few of the points that were raised in the debate to put some things into perspective and correct some things. The total costs for grain and horticultural inspections amount to $8m, as stated by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), with $4m recoverable in a full year, but $2m was already recovered through existing charges. The $100 per hour figure for market-based exporters is not strictly accurate. It reflects the pattern of phytosanitary certificate issue-I will get on to that in a moment-but the structure of fees is currently under review. The reason we are reviewing it after all this consultation with industry is that we found, as we found in other industries-I well recall aspects of fisheries inspection where we put the charging into place and we are moving to a fee for service, wherever we possibly can-that there were anomalies that we could correct. As I say, I will get onto that in a moment. The new inspection arrangements are currently being finalised. Costing details have been available on request from my Department since the new fees were introduced and industry costings not accurate with respect to estimated revenue will not be exceeded on current indications.

The phytosanitary certificate fee is not double charging. It represents the cost of developing, maintaining and updating product standards required by overseas countries and the cost is visible to exporters in terms of actual inspector effort. As I said, there is a review under way. We have already identified 65 bodies to be involved in the review. We are still gathering charge statistics and again we will be going through the whole process. We will be contacting industry bodies within the next few years, as promised. We propose to adopt in this review the approach of providing an analysis of the charges over the first two months. We propose a series of alternatives of getting the 50 per cent recovery, including one for the orchid exporters, which are of particular concern, and we are inviting comments from the bodies concerned on any other possible alternatives. During this time we will be setting up a working party comprising representatives of the five or six major industry sectors and the States, which carry out this inspection on the Commonwealth's behalf, as I have already stated, under the Commonwealth's chairmanship. The working party will examine industry responses and bring forward recommendations it considers appropriate. There is no reason why the working party cannot bring forward the recommendations before the end of April.

I will end where I started. I thank people for contributing to this debate. I believe that, with horticultural exports and exports of floriculture and now with plant variety rights exports, we will be developing new species for export overseas. I believe that some of the comments of members on both sides of the House did present the exciting prospects in this general area. But if we are to export to the world, we need to be able to give phytosanitary certificates to importing countries because of their quarantine requirements, the same quarantine requirements that we have in this country and the ones that we apply to other countries as they export to us. The taxpayer subsidises 50 per cent of that charge. As I pointed out, there is an enormous amount of consultation. There are areas where we believe there are anomalies that may be solved and we are setting up a review process at the outset of this charging regime to try to fix these problems. It is for these reasons that the Government rejects the Opposition's amendment.
