TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to address two matters: first of all, I wish to say something about the Diplomatic and Consular Privileges Amendment Bill; and, secondly, I wish to move and to speak to the amendment which has been circulated in my name. The Diplomatic and Consular Privileges Amendment Bill is designed to amend two Acts, the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act 1967 and the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972. Its purpose is to provide that tax imposed under any of the various sales tax Acts is not payable in respect of goods intended for the official use, and not resale, of a diplomatic mission or consular post of a prescribed overseas country provided the goods are purchased from a registered sales taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: This is fairly dry stuff but there is good reason behind the Bill. The reasons are these: the amendments are the result of increasing difficulties Australia is experiencing overseas in claiming exemption for its missions and posts from sales tax and value added tax (VAT). Under the two relevant conventions on diplomatic and consular relations, personnel at foreign missions and posts are exempt from direct taxes but have a liability to pay indirect taxes of the kinds which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services. The Australian Government has maintained that the Australian sales tax is an indirect tax and payable by foreign missions and posts, whereas the United States of America and western European sales tax and VAT are direct taxes from which Australian personnel are exempt. This interpretation of the two conventions has been disputed, and on a number of occasions other countries have sought to collect sales tax and VAT not only from Australian personnel but also from Australian missions and posts. Therefore, to maintain Australian exemption overseas it may be necessary, while upholding our interpretation of the conventions, to grant certain companies exemption from Australian sales tax in respect of their official purchases. Amendments to the two Acts are therefore brought forward.

It is intended that as a matter of policy a foreign state will be proclaimed a prescribed overseas country and therefore have the benefit of the exemption only where Australia is receiving a reciprocal exemption from sales tax or VAT and where the cost of providing sales tax exemptions in Australia is outweighed by the financial benefits of such reciprocal exemption. That is a rather curious policy objective in the sense that it is more than a little difficult to see how in practice it can be determined that the future operation of a reciprocal exemption will, in fact, operate to Australia's benefit. That is something that can be worked out in the administration of the scheme proposed by the Bill. I now move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House believes that the confirmation of locally-imposed tax exemption for personnel and missions should be supported, but is of the opinion that the morale of professional officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been severely affected by this Government's abuse of political appointments to diplomatic postings, and that such political appointments, coupled with the consequent adverse effect on morale, are not in Australia's public and international interests'.

The foreign service is the foundation of policy advice for the purposes of determining Australia's foreign policy. It provides intelligence, opinions, assessments and advice. It is very truly the eyes and ears of Australia overseas. It demands highly skilled and highly qualified people. If it does not have highly skilled and highly qualified people, Australia suffers. It suffers in representation and it suffers in making decisions on questions that affect our interests overseas, decisions that may be of great importance to this country. The foreign service under this Government has become the trough for the greedy, for the desperate, and for the discarded. It has become a dumping ground for politicians and it has become politicised. Damage has been done to the morale of the foreign service and to its ethos. There are of course justifications for outside appointments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. With respect to the honourable member, what he is raising in the House, as I anticipated would be his intention, has absolutely nothing to do with the Bill before the House and under the Standing Orders cannot be introduced.

—It has been the custom of the House to have fairly wide ranging debates on second readings of Bills. The honourable member for North Sydney has moved an amendment that all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting other words which particularly relate to matters of personnel and things which come generally in the ambit of the debate.
—It is always a very useful thing to be in at the beginning so that objections can be made then.
—Order! The honourable member might continue with the debate rather than pursuing the point of order.

—Yes. There are justifiable outside appointments and there are cases where members of this House, through experience and the positions they have held, should be qualified to go to particular posts. In the past governments have certainly from time to time misused appointments to the foreign service, but nothing has been like the practice under this Government, when we have seen the sleeze factor rampant. No question of qualification arises. It seems that membership of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), membership of this House or former membership of this House, a connection with the Labor Party, is all that is needed. It is as though there is a claim of right of legitimacy to the spoils. Indeed, one could say of the Australian Labor Party that it has done one thing very effectively in the case of the foreign service-it has reinvented the spoils system. If ever there were an exemplification of it, it was the views of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden). The Foreign Minister is a very outspoken man and he is remarkably and refreshingly candid in his views about things. We know that he is a republican by nature. In the last few days the Prime Minister, who appears to have some difference of recollection with the Foreign Minister over events, said, `Yes, of course if Bill wants to be the next Governor-General he should be the next Governor-General'. It is as though he were handing out candy to a baby. That is the way in which it is treated.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the appointments that have been made since 1983 under the Hawke Government. Mr Gough Whitlam was appointed Ambassador to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation; Dr Harry Jenkins was appointed Ambassador to Spain; Mr Doug McClelland was appointed High Commissioner to London; Mr David Combe, a man the Labor Party dearly wanted to get out of this country, was appointed Trade Commissioner to Vancouver; Mr Alan Oxley, a former adviser to John Cain, Premier of Victoria, was appointed Ambassador to GATT-General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; Mr Ross Garnaut, a former economic adviser to Mr Hawke, was appointed Ambassador to China; Mr Richard Butler, former adviser to Mr Whitlam, was appointed Ambassador for Disarmament, a position that has since been junked because the Foreign Minister's preoccupation with disarmament seems to have waned somewhat; Mr Ian Taylor, a former Western Australian Labor Deputy Premier, was appointed Administrator of Christmas Island; Dr Don Grimes was appointed Ambassador to the Netherlands; Mr Tom Burns, Deputy Leader of the ALP in Queensland, was offered, I understand, as a means of settling a factional row, the position of Ambassador to Greece; Mr Bill Morrison, who I would say is a former foreign service officer of longstanding, was appointed Ambassador to Jakarta; Mr Les Johnson was appointed Ambassador to Wellington; and recently we had those glittering diplomatic luminaries, Mr Brian Burke, who was appointed Ambassador to Ireland, and Mr Chris Hurford who was appointed Consul-General to New York.

I should like to take three examples to analyse the kind of damage these sorts of appointments can do. Let us take the appointment of Dr Harry Jenkins. When I saw the announcement that was made by the Foreign Minister on the appointment of Dr Harry Jenkins I thought for a moment that his well known sense of humour had got the better of him. This is what was said in a news release of 16 March 1986:
Mr Hayden said today that Dr Jenkins was a distinguished parliamentarian who would bring a wide range of abilities, experience and personal qualities to the task of representing Australia overseas.
Dr Jenkins was certainly here for a long time-for 25 years-and before that he was a doctor. The news release continued:
Mr Hayden said that Dr Jenkins' appointment reflects the importance-
I ask the House to listen to those words-
Australia attaches to its relations with Spain, particularly following Spain's entry to the European Economic Community on 1 January 1986.

Reflecting the importance we attach to Spain, this Government appointed a man aged 60 who had retired from this House, as we all believe, because of ill health-we all know the difficulties Dr Jenkins had because of the injury or damage to his leg-who spoke not a word of Spanish, who had been to Spain once, on his own admission, in 1980, but who regarded himself as singularly well qualified for the job. The Age interviewed Dr Jenkins. He said, according to the Age of 8 January 1986, that he loved the Madrid art gallery, the Prado, and believed that his 25 years' experience as a member of parliament qualified him for such a job.

What possible qualification does sitting around this House for 25 years provide to represent this country overseas? None. If the Foreign Minister and his Government were in the least concerned about our representation in Spain they should have borne in mind that the Spanish are very proud people, that they have a language, and that if one goes there-and I suggest that one does-they like one to speak that language. Dr Jenkins says disarmingly that he has even mastered the Spanish phrase `Would you mind saying that a little more slowly, please?'. One can see him these days saying, `Por favor, hombre, lentamente', and perhaps, `Habla usted Ingles?'. As I understand it-the information comes back to me-Dr Jenkins has yet to learn to speak Spanish. My information is that he does not enjoy the post. He does not speak Spanish and I am informed further that a female secretary was denied a posting to Madrid because of her sex. Amongst other things, her job was to assist Dr Jenkins physically in a number of ways, including helping him get in and out of cars. Because of her sex-and this is from a government that prides itself upon its affirmation of equality-she was denied that job. If the information is wrong I shall be glad to hear from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade on that subject. So here we have a man who cannot even read the morning papers in Spanish, who cannot conduct a conversation in Spanish, who places the burden therefore on the professional people in Madrid and is entirely dependent on their advice.

Next, I turn to Premier Burke. What possible qualifications did this man have for the job? What debt was he owed? Honourable members know that Premier Burke retired in his mid-40s after five years as Premier of Western Australia. He retired with considerable superannuation and he got a nice, easy, plum posting in Ireland. What are his qualifications? He is a member of the Labor club. He has his snout in the trough and that is enough, along with every other member of the Labor club. On his appointment the Australian Financial Review of 23 December 1987 reported:
This is more than the total of similar appointments by the Fraser Government-and in about half the time.
It was also reported in the same article:
The Foreign Affairs and Trade Association, the staff body for Australian diplomats, said the appointment would be a further blow to the low morale of the Australian foreign service.
The association should say that, as in fact it was. Perhaps revealingly, the article continued:

Mr Burke's diplomatic posting reflects a view at senior levels of the Government that the Australian diplomatic service should involve a considerable number of political appointees to key diplomatic posts.

Mr Hayden has made it known that he favours the US system of a highly politicised diplomatic service in which the administration appoints people with political backgrounds to represent the political attitudes of the administration more effectively.

That kind of politicisation represents the destruction of a highly professional, highly competent foreign service. Perhaps that is what the Minister wants, perhaps that is what the Government wants-certainly that is the way it is going. Let me turn to the third and perhaps the most humorous appointment. That is the appointment, seven days after the announcement of Mr Burke's appointment, of Mr Chris Hurford-a glittering nonentity, dropped from the Ministry or dropped by his factions. His appointment was announced by the Foreign Minister on 31 December 1987. As I pointed out, he was getting to be a pretty dab hand at announcing the appointments of Labor colleagues who had decided to move to greener pastures or who, having been kicked out, wanted plum jobs or who had made good deals with their factions or factional agreements with the Government. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade in a Press release said:
Mr Hurford, with his strong economic and political background was well-qualified for the post.
That was the post of Consul-General in New York. The Foreign Minister's news release went on:

Mr Hurford entered Parliament in 1969. In Opposition he served as Shadow Treasurer and Shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce. Since 1983 he has been the Minister for Housing and Construction, Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Minister for Community Services and Minister Assisting the Treasurer.

Honourable members will notice that none of those, save the last, has any possible bearing upon finance in the way that is understood in the city of New York. Honourable members know why he was Minister Assisting the Treasurer. He was there to sign the Treasurer's correspondence because the Treasurer will not sign it himself. He is too busy engaged on other matters.

Of all posts, New York is in some ways the most high-powered, critical and demanding in the financial scene. Mr Hurford is an extremely decent man. I made the criticisms I now make of him while he was still a member of this House and to his face. He did not like them. I can understand that, but what will this decent man, known around here as Moo or Scoop, do in New York? He will be lost in that city. He will be left behind by the financial community which will regard him, and the Government in sending out this nice, kindly man to New York, as some kind of eccentric joke. He will not understand what the name of the game is in that tough city.

What has been the consequence of all this? Morale has suffered. Everyone who has anything to do with the Australian foreign service knows that. We have seen careers displaced and disrupted. For example, when Mr Burke was appointed to Ireland he took over from a career officer who had been there for a little more than one year. The more non-career officers who are appointed, the more politicians who are appointed, the more hangers-on of the Labor Party who are appointed, and the more failed, retired or exhausted Labor Party politicians who are appointed, the more damage is done to morale and the greater the strain imposed on the foreign service. Somebody has to do the hard work. Somebody has to make the assessments. Honourable members should not think that it is just a matter of getting up and scanning the local papers, if one can read the language, and writing home. At its best it is difficult, demanding and highly expert work.

This factor, that is, the damage to morale, has been compounded by the obvious politicisation of the foreign service and the downgrading of professionalism that has accompanied this Government. I understand that if one wishes to join the foreign service these days one is no longer required as a matter of course to go overseas. The advertisement says that one can go overseas if it is mutually acceptable, as though it was just like any other service. No doubt the Minister believes that, because that is the way he administers his foreign service. That has led to the destruction of much of the professionalism in his own foreign service. If honourable members want a foreign service like the American foreign service I can only say this: some of the American representatives overseas are good; some are appalling. Overall, I believe that in the past our foreign service at the middle and top levels has been very much better.

To conclude what I am saying on this subject, what we have seen is a symptom of a wider disease, a corruption of the political spirit in the Labor Party. It was exemplified once again today by the Prime Minister, who told us that he made a few telephone calls to a few friends when Mr Young went out. Of course, what that does, although apparently he does not realise it, is to put him under an obligation to any of those friends who help Mr Young. They are entitled to say later, `Look, Bob, we helped you with Mick. Now we would like sympathetic consideration for a view we have to put to you. Can we come and see you?'. The Prime Minister will have many calls to make in the future. We may see an exodus from the Party. We believe a few bodies will go from this place in the next few months. Whether we see that exodus, one thing that needs to be done and will be done when we return to power after the next election is to review the political appointments made by this Government and to restore the morale and professionalism of Australia's foreign service.

SPEECH.PARA: Having put the comments of the honourable member for North Sydney to rest I now request the Government to look at a decision it has made with regard to overseas postings. The matter to which I ask the Government to turn is the sale of Australian Embassy land in Japan. I have reservations about that sale and the Government's decision in that regard. The sale of the land would realise for the Government in excess of $500m. I may be a fraction out in the calculation of the acreage but I believe the land is just over 1.5 acres in size. Land values, therefore, in Tokyo are between $350m and $400m an acre. I realise that some find that incredible, but what I have said is the absolute truth. I have not misquoted any figures. Whilst one could argue that such a return would be good for the Budget now, I believe that down the track we will find that the portion retained for the ambassador's residence and diplomatic area in Tokyo will be incredibly cramped. We will be handing the Cabinet of the day in about 10 years time a rather large problem. We will have to rent premises. Obviously, we will not buy premises when the cost of land is $400m an acre. We will have to rent, and one can imagine the rent scales at that land cost. Recently I read a survey which showed that rents in Tokyo were seven times higher than rents in Singapore. Although this return may be good for the Budget now, the Cabinet of 1998 may not thank us when the bill for renting premises in Tokyo reaches an astronomical figure.

I should like the Government to review its decision and consider whether it has made the correct decision. I understand that a lot of money is involved; around the $600m mark. I am sure the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would not be too happy about letting that sort of money go. However, this is a long term proposition. I am not talking only about the gardens that are in the embassy grounds. If the land is sold, those gardens will be replaced. I am suggesting that, even if the land were not sold, the gardens may have to be replaced in the not too distant future as a result of the accommodation problems that we will have.

At present we have many people in Tokyo and that number will obviously increase, not decrease. Only a matter of weeks ago I visited the Embassy and its grounds. The problem only really comes home when ones sees it in totality, surrounded by the massive infrastructure in Tokyo at present. I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) to give the Minister for Finance a further nudge on this subject. It is important for the future operations of our diplomatic service in Tokyo.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has done a fine job in his portfolio, particularly in the diplomatic area. For example, the quality of our representation in the South Pacific has increased dramatically. The Minister took a quite conscious decision to upgrade our representation in the South Pacific. That decision was acknowledged at a public meeting of the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee recently when a number of well-qualified witnesses agreed that the quality of our representation had increased markedly during the past few years under the guidance of the Minister.

Appointments to the South Pacific used to be purely for retiring members of a government. Although the Opposition bleats about the South Pacific now, its members did not attempt to put together a coherent package of representation policies. This Government has done that and we are starting to see the fruits of that now. There is still a way to go and none of us here pretends to have all the answers to all the problems. However, we are a long way down the track from where we were when we came to government just over five years ago. I am sure I have successfully debunked the galling speech made by the honourable member for North Sydney. It was absolute nonsense. This Government has nothing to be ashamed of. It has selected people of high quality for important postings. The Minister, in conjunction with a Cabinet, will obviously continue to do just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that just for a change I might turn to the Diplomatic and Consular Privileges Amendment Bill and discuss some aspects of it. This Bill has been introduced because the Government is claiming that it will overcome difficulties which, it is said, are being experienced in some overseas countries in obtaining exemption for our diplomatic missions and posts from paying certain sales and value added taxes. By making provision in this Bill for the Australian Government to exempt a prescribed foreign country from paying Australian sales tax it will achieve reciprocity for our diplomats serving in overseas countries. That concepts seems to be quite simple and its application appears to be uncontentious, but there are aspects of it which not only puzzle me but also have encouraged me to give consideration to the wider question of conditions of service for Australia's diplomatic personnel.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to go back to the very basis of the Bill, namely, the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations, which was agreed to in Vienna on 18 April 1961, signed by Australia on 30 March 1962 and entered into force for Australia on 25 February 1968. Article 34 of that Convention states:
A diplomatic agent shall be exempt from all dues and taxes, personal or real, national, regional or municipal, except:
(A) indirect taxes of a kind which are normally incorporated in the price of goods or services. . .

And it goes on at length. The intention of that provision seems perfectly clear. Diplomatic staff must pay sales tax and other indirect taxes of the kinds that are normally included in the price of goods and services. Yet the Bill before us today provides for the Australian Government to exempt certain foreign countries from the payment of such taxes. One has to ask why. In the explanatory memorandum attached to the Bill we are informed:
Due to the manner in which sales tax operates in this country-
that is, Australia-

the Government has always taken the view that Australian sales tax is an indirect tax and as such must be paid by foreign missions and posts. However, the Government has also taken the view that certain foreign sales tax and value added tax systems, due to the manner in which they operate, are direct taxes and as such do not apply to personnel at our missions and posts. The divergence of these interpretations has increased between Australia and some foreign countries to the point where amendments to the legislation are necessary as a mechanism to achieve reciprocity and mutual benefit.

That goes to the nub of the matter. I want to describe this problem in my hopefully uncomplicated way. Australia is a signatory to a treaty which requires diplomats to pay indirect taxes such as sales and value added taxes. Some foreign countries have sales and value added taxes which they regard as indirect taxes but which Australia does not because of the way they are applied. As a result, the Australian Government is insisting to those foreign countries that those taxes are not really indirect taxes and, therefore, need not be paid by Australian diplomats.

It seems to me that these circumstances raise three distinct issues. The first is to consider the intention of the Vienna Treaty; the second is whether the action of the Australian Government is in keeping with that intention; and the third is to consider whether there might not be an administratively more efficient means of overcoming this problem. The intention of the Vienna Convention is unambiguous. It simply seeks to have diplomatic staff pay the sorts of taxes that are normally added to or included with goods and services such as buying vegetables, clothing, toothbrushes or whatever.

Unless there is information about the nature of the overseas sales and value added taxes system which has not been brought to our attention, the facts before us suggest that there is an overseas country which applies sales and/or value added taxes and identifies them as indirect taxes. Australia refuses to accept that identification because of the particular manner in which those taxes are being applied. Is our refusal in keeping with the intention of the Vienna Convention? The answer would appear to be no. As I understand the situation, our concern about the manner in which these taxes are being applied is largely irrelevant when one acknowledges that in the country of their application they are identified as sales and value added taxes, regarded as indirect taxes by that overseas country and added to or included in the price of goods and services.

I cannot help but feel that Australia is being far too pedantic on this matter, particularly when there are numerous examples of the Australian Government having accepted, without reservation, the proposition that value added taxes are indirect taxes. Consider, for example, the June 1985 White Paper, Reform of the Australian Tax System. Appendix 13b is devoted to a consideration of the value added tax (VAT) and the broad based consumption tax and states:
A VAT is a multistage sales tax on consumer goods and services . . .
Whether one applies either a VAT or another tax system, the paper states:
The consumer bears that full incidence of the tax.
Furthermore, it states:
The United States and Canada have had long experience with retail sales taxes . . .
Again it states:

Most European countries have adopted a VAT rather than a BBCT. The explanation for this lies mainly in the history of indirect taxation in Europe and in the requirements for tax harmonisation within the European Community.

The point I am making is that in an Australian Government White Paper there is no hesitation in referring to value added taxes and broad based consumption taxes, as they are applied in America and Europe, as being synonymous with sales taxes and indirect taxation. Why then our reluctance to do so for the purpose of the Vienna Convention? Are there reasons, unstated in the explanatory memorandum, which are causing the Australian Government to be so adamant on this matter of definition that it seeks to enshrine its point of view in legislation-or are we witnessing a piece of misplaced intransigence?

This leads to the third issue-whether this Bill is the most effective means of achieving reciprocity between countries on the matter of sales tax. I do not think this for a moment. Indeed, I would go further and suggest that the existence of special reciprocity provisions in legislative form will actually add to Australia's administrative problems over time. I cannot help but return to the simple proposition that the best administrative solution would appear to lie in the Australian Government accepting that the form of sales tax being used overseas is indirect taxation within the intention of the Vienna Convention. That this is so is reinforced by the existence of two provisions in the Bill before us, namely, clauses 4 and 5.

Clause 4 provides for this legislation to be made retrospective to 1 July 1987. The reason for this, the explanatory memorandum tells us, is to give legislative backing to an arrangement between Australia and the United States that they will grant sales tax exemption in respect of goods purchased by the mission and posts of the other party. Can we accept, from the existence of such an arrangement, that the disagreement over the definition of indirect taxation is largely between Australia and the United States, and that those differences have not only been impossible to resolve in terms of the Vienna Convention, but have led to a letter of arrangement between the two countries, and now subsequently to legislative backing.

There is an implication here that there has been a longstanding dispute with the United States over this matter. It compounds my concern as to whether Australia is not being unduly obdurate in insisting that what the United States considers to be an indirect tax is not so regarded by us. Furthermore, we have obviously taken that insistence through an initial stage of putting it in the form of a letter of understanding between the two countries and now into a final stage of the full weight and authority of legislative enactment. This seems incredibly strong action for an administrative matter which one would have expected to be resolved at departmental level.

My puzzlement increases further when we come to a consideration of clause 5 of the Bill and its associated comments in the explanatory memorandum. Clause 5 merely amends section 4 of the principal Act by inserting a definition of `prescribed overseas country' and of `registered person'. But, in commenting on those insertions in the explanatory memorandum, that document tells us:
A country will be prescribed by regulations only where the foreign state is providing reciprocal treatment to Australia; and it is in Australia's financial interest to do so.

So, not only are we sticking to our guns and insisting to the world that our definition of what constitutes an indirect tax is correct, but we will grant reciprocal exemptions only where it is in our financial interest to do so. What does that mean-that we will grant reciprocal exemptions only where there is financial neutrality, or where there is a financial advantage to Australia? The answer is provided elsewhere in the explanatory memorandum, under the heading `Financial Impact Statement'. This states that we will proclaim a prescribed country only where the financial benefits to Australia outweigh the cost of granting sales tax exemption in Australia.

That is an incredibly long way from the intentions of the Vienna Convention. Not only is Australia now insisting on special bilateral exemption provisions, but also those exemption provisions must be to our financial advantage. I suggest to the House and to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) that a requirement to calculate financial benefit seems to present an almost impossible administrative task. How does one effectively calculate the amount of sales tax to be forgone over a period by the diplomatic staff of a particular foreign country and compare that to a similar loss of sales tax by our diplomats in their country? One has only to think about that to see how stupid and nonsensical it is.

All this leads me to speculate whether it might not be to our financial advantage and administratively simpler to accept that the system of sales tax used by the United States is an indirect tax and must therefore be paid by Australian diplomatic staff. I would be very interested to be informed by the Government as to the value of sales tax involved in these exemption proposals and to compare that to the cost of preparing the letter of understanding with the United States, the cost of this Bill and the ongoing costs of administering the regulations which this legislation will create.

Nothing that I have said so far should in any way suggest that I want to increase the financial hardship for Australian personnel in overseas missions and posts; quite the reverse. Their working environment is already a most unenviable and dangerous one in many countries, particularly those where there is a likelihood of terrorist incidents, civil disorders and serious levels of domestic crime. While the heavy officialism which is identified in this Bill is somewhat puzzling, I can appreciate that the benefits it seeks to achieve are very important to staff who are located in those countries where the matter of indirect taxation has become an issue. This concern may also point to the broader question of the conditions of service applicable to Australia's diplomatic staff, and in particular their allowances. It is a matter of public record that there are continuing difficulties and discontent within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade over the revised overseas living allowance system introduced about 18 months ago. I understand this system was intended to improve the remunerative conditions for overseas staff but it certainly has not been well received, and little wonder. It is more complex than the system it replaced, it has actually created rather than removed disincentives to overseas service, and it is more difficult than its predecessor to administer. If we add to that the well publicised difficulties within the Department in integrating its recently acquired trade responsibilities, we gain a picture of one of Australia's most important and respected departments in a state of considerable instability.

I readily acknowledge that the sales tax issue being addressed in this Bill would be only a very small part of the totality of factors making up the conditions of service for overseas staff and the less than satisfactory working environment presently being experienced within that Department, but I cannot help but wonder whether the inadequacies we have seen with the introduction of the overseas living allowance and the absorption of the old Department of Trade are not also being reflected in the manner in which the Department is attempting to resolve its indirect taxation dilemma with the United States. I do not think it is unreasonable to suggest that, had the overseas living allowance been properly designed, it might have incorporated an allowance for this sales tax difficulty and obviated the need for special legislation and its supporting regulations.

The shadow Minister has made his comments about the Bill and has moved an amendment which goes to the very great concern so many people feel that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is being progressively downgraded by the burden of rejected Government members it is required to absorb. But that, in essence, is another issue. The fact remains that we have here a piece of unnecessary legislation. The cost of drawing up the legislation must have been considerable, the objective which led to its drawing up is questionable, and the thinking behind it is very much open to question. In fact, it does give the appearance of something placed before the Minister either shortly before or shortly after he went on one of his frequent overseas trips, and he has signed it, saying, `Well, that seems like a good idea'. It is a little like the good-idea-at-the-time syndrome that we have seen exemplified in recent years in the Senate.

I urge the Government to have a close look at this piece of legislation. I do not think it is necessary. We are not opposing the Bill's second reading; we simply suggest that a consideration of it would show any clear minded person that it is unnecessary, it is administratively complex, it is expensive, and it should not have been brought in in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This necessary and excellent piece of legislation, the Diplomatic and Consular Privileges Amendment Bill, will amend the Diplomatic Privileges and Immunities Act of 1967 and the Consular Privileges and Immunities Act of 1972. The Bill provides, inter alia, that goods purchased from registered sales tax payers for the official use of missions and posts of prescribed overseas countries shall be exempt from Australian sales tax. The Governor-General has the power to make regulations proclaiming particular foreign states to be prescribed overseas countries. The then Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments have become necessary due to increasing criticism which Australia has received in relation to our interpretation of particular provisions of the two Vienna Conventions.

Those conventions, of course, were on diplomatic and consular relations. I understand the origin of this Bill can be traced back to disputes over the meaning of direct and indirect taxes. The definitions of direct and indirect taxes, according to economic textbooks, are quite simple. However, the practical application of the definitions is apparently not so simple. Direct taxes are sometimes defined as those which are imposed directly on and paid by those who are ultimately to bear the burden of the taxes-for example, income tax, capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax. Indirect taxes are sometimes defined as those which are imposed on taxpayers who are expected to shift the burden to others. Examples of indirect taxes are consumption taxes such as sales tax and value added tax. The legal liability to pay the tax to the taxation authorities is with the seller of the goods or services but the person who will ultimately bear the burden of the tax is the consumer, hence the title `indirect'.

The Minister for Trade Negotiations in his second reading speech stated that the Australian Government has been of the view that the Australian sales tax system is an indirect tax but the `sales tax and value added tax systems operated by the United States of America and certain western European countries are direct taxes'. There is a difference between the sales tax systems operating in Australia and the United States of America. The general policy of the legislation in Australia is to levy tax upon the sale to the retailer by the last wholesaler in the chain. If there is no middle man the sales tax is levied on the sale by the manufacturer to the retailer. It is the last wholesaler who is liable to pay the tax to the taxation authorities. By the time the final consumer purchases the item the amount of sales tax paid has been lost in the price.

In the United States of America sales tax is levied on the retail price of goods. Generally the retail price tag of an item is marked with the before tax price. The tax is added at the time of the purchase. Therefore, although it is the retailer who actually collects and passes the tax to the taxation authorities, the consumer is aware of how much tax has been paid on the article.

It is probably the ability, or lack of it, to identify the sales tax component in the retail sales price which causes the confusion as to whether the tax is direct or indirect. For example, with the United States system the ultimate taxpayer, that is, the consumer, knows how much sales tax has been paid whereas an Australian consumer does not know and, generally speaking, gives little thought to the matter. Further, until recent reforms were made the United States Federal tax system allowed individual consumers an income tax deduction for sales tax paid as if the tax were a direct tax.

In Australia it is generally the last wholesaler who pays the tax to the authorities. Transactions after that point do not refer to the tax component in the price. To overcome the difficulties associated with a person buying at the retail level and claiming exemption from the tax, this Bill provides in clauses 7 and 12, among other things, that in Australia goods must be purchased directly from a registered manufacturer or wholesale merchant. Clause 5 of the Bill refers to `registered person' who is required to lodge Australian sales tax returns.

In 1985 the United States withdrew sales tax exemption from our diplomatic and consular missions and personnel and argued that Australia was not providing a similar exemption to its mission and posts in Australia. During bilateral negotiations it was agreed that, first, Australia would retain its United States exemptions in full, and, second, the United States would be exempt in respect of the official purchases of diplomatic and consular missions, provided that the purchases were made from a registered sales tax payer, that is, wholesaler. This understanding is in line with our longstanding position that the Vienna conventions do not require us to grant exemptions to privileged personnel from indirect sales tax at the retail level. Indeed, article 34 of the 1961 Convention refers to that point.

The settlement is in Australia's financial interests, as the cost of granting exemption to the United States would be about $185,000 per annum while the benefit of retaining our exemption in the United States would be approximately $800,000 per annum. I understand that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has agreed, in the short term, to use his powers under the Audit Act 1901 to reimburse the United States for sales tax paid by United States missions and posts on official purchases made after 1 July 1987. However, it is necessary, in the long term, to provide a specific statutory basis for the exemption.

Rather than simply legislating to grant the exemption to United States missions and posts, the Hawke Government decided to enact a more general provision under which other countries could be granted similar exemptions where it was in Australia's interest to do so. These amendments to the Diplomatic (Privileges and Immunities) Act and the Consular (Privileges and Immunities) Act will continue the process of consolidating all legislation dealing with diplomatic and consular missions within Acts administered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The two Acts give effect to Australia's legal obligation under the Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations of 1961 and the Vienna Convention on Consular Relations of 1963. Those two conventions represent a codification and clarification of the rules of diplomatic and consular law which had been developing among states for over 200 years. To date, more than 150 countries have become a party to the conventions.

The amendments proposed in the Bill follow very closely existing provisions dealing with exemption from customs and excise duties-that is, sections 8 and 9 of the Diplomatic (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1967 and sections 6 and 7 of the Consular (Privileges and Immunity) Act 1972. The only substantive difference is that, under these amendments, only missions and posts of a foreign country are exempt from sales tax, while under the existing provisions the missions, posts and personnel of a foreign country are exempt from customs and excise duty. The Hawke Government is willing to negotiate with other countries as necessary, provided that there is a clear financial advantage to Australia. Clauses 7 and 12 of the Bill also provide several safeguards against sales tax avoidance including the provision for the Treasurer to declare that a mission has sufficient goods of a particular kind to meet its reasonable needs. While such a declaration is in force the mission would not be able to claim the sales tax exemption on those articles.

This piece of legislation is necessary, reasonable, and well thought out, and it is the type of legislation that deserved a better contribution from the two Opposition members who have spoken in this debate. The first of them-the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender)-did not do himself justice or credit in his speech this evening. I expected a much better standard from him, particularly in his gratuitous and insulting references to former members of this House. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) criticised the Bill. I do not know where he got his information from, but even a cursory examination of the implications for the application of indirect and direct taxes, as has been interpreted by the Australian authorities relating to article 34 of the 1961 Convention, should have convinced him immediately of the need for a statutory basis if any exemptions are to be applied to any country, whether it is the United States or anywhere else. The contributions from the Opposition have been disappointing. Both honourable members are capable of a much better contribution. Their performances this evening do not bring them or the Opposition any credit.

I commend this Bill to the House. It is necessary, as I said, to give statutory effect to the exemptions that can be applied under the Act. It is another hallmark of the excellent job being performed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) in the administration of his Department on behalf of our country.

It is correct that there has been some dispute as to what the Vienna conventions mean when they refer to taxes and whether they cover indirect taxes or only direct taxes. That is a view that has been held by a succession of governments, not only by this Labor Government but also by earlier Liberal- Country Party governments. SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) raised some queries about the mission in Tokyo. I think it was built at around the turn of the century or some time in the early part of this century, judging by the style of it, by a Japanese nobleman. SPEECH.PARA: Then there was Roberton. I remember Roberton when he was Minister for Social Services in this House, when I first came here. The late Annabelle Rankin went to Wellington. She was a Minister in the Senate before she went there. She had that distinction. Fairbairn, a Liberal, went to the Hague in 1977. He could not speak a word of Dutch before he left here and he could not speak a word of it when he finished his period there. John McLeay left school at about 14 years of age and sold carpets until he arrived here. He went to Los Angeles as the Consul-General. If we go back to the Menzies days, we find that there are clutches and clutches of worn-out military officers who presumably were mates of his that he had known from around Canberra. There are stacks and stacks of them here. If we go to the people who have been appointed by the Labor Party as heads of mission overseas, in all cases in the period I have been Foreign Minister I am satisfied that they are more than competent to handle the range of tasks which are before them. I say this also: the Liberal and Country parties having invented the business of political appointees and its having become well entrenched over the very long period they were in government until 1972-23 years-I do not think that they should be the ones to be casting stones if the Labor Party in government should follow a well-established precedent that they put in place and persisted with under Fraser.

I do not think that the honourable member for North Sydney has particular credibility when he stands up and condemns these people, when his own father was the first beneficiary of a system of political appointments to heads of mission. The fact is that Liberal-Country Party governments have put covenants on the past, invented this sort of practice, put it into place and pursued it with persistent enthusiasm. All we have done is to follow the standards they have laid down.

The only other thing I want to say is this: the people we have selected have been selected because they are people of proven competence. We are confident that they will do a good job. Many of the people that the Liberal-Country Party put into positions overseas as heads of mission also served with distinction and did good jobs. But if we are going to go into the business of trying to score cheap points at the expense of people's reputations, both sides of the House can do it. I do not think it is terribly productive and it is not terribly elevating.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill before the House tonight is extremely crucial to the future of democracy in this country. I say that because we are dealing with one of the most basic platforms of our democratic system-the calling of a referendum, the referral of an important matter relating to our Constitution or other facets of life here in Australia to the people for them to choose, to decide and to determine the outcome of these important issues. Fundamental in the successful running of any referendum or election must be the people's faith in and the integrity of the system that runs those elections or referenda. It is fundamental because, if people do not believe in the integrity of the electoral system, have confidence in its administration and accept its results, democracy will eventually fail. All of us in this Parliament could cite examples of countries that lose that confidence by weakening the integrity of the electoral system to the point where no-one believes or trusts in elections or referendums and, as a consequence, anarchy eventually prevails.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight we deal with changes to the Commonwealth Electoral Act as they relate to the holding of referendums. The Opposition recognises that there is a need from time to time to finetune the electoral processes. We recognise too that this is an extremely complex and difficult area in which to enact change as so often the full ramifications of these changes are not fully understood until after an election, when it can possibly result in weakening the strength and security of the electoral processes in a way not previously thought of. We appreciate the difficulties encountered by any government in making reforms in this area. In tonight's debate let me make it quite plain that I do not intend to try to score political points from the Government over this legislation. Rather, we, in our amendments, make known to the Parliament and the people what our genuine concerns are and the reasons for them in the hope that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) will take them on board, consider them and adopt them-not, as I said, for any political gain to us, but rather for the benefit of this Parliament, the people of Australia and our democratic way of life. Having said all that, the Opposition intends to move three amendments deleting clause 8 (b), clause 10 and the first four amendments to subsection 30.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very significant amendments.

—As the honourable member for Farrer points out, these are significant amendments. I believe they are crucial to the stable and efficient running of our democracy in the future. If these amendments are not agreed to in the committee stage, the Opposition will vote against the legislation and will look forward to the Senate debate in the hope that our shadow Minister, Senator Jim Short, and the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) can come to some agreement. This Bill has come forward in response to the work done by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and the recommendations it has made to the Parliament relating to the operations of the electoral reforms enacted for the 1984 general election. May I just say on behalf of the Opposition how much the work done by the Joint Select Committee is appreciated.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give honourable members some background to this legislation: in its 1986 report No. 2, the Joint Select Committee made a large number of recommendations-I think there were some 150 of them-for amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in light of the experience gained at the 1984 general election, which was the first election held after the fundamental revision of the Act in 1983-84. The Government announced in early 1987 that it accepted most of the Joint Select Committee's recommendations and that legislation to give effect to the acceptable recommendations would be introduced in stages. In May and June 1987, the Electoral Act was amended prior to the July election to give effect to those recommendations considered essential for implementation before that election.

There are many common provisions in both the Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, which is an Act relating to the submission to the electors of proposed laws for the alteration of the Constitution. This Bill proposes amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act to incorporate the same changes that were made to the Electoral Act in June 1987, thereby restoring the pre-June 1987 consistency between the two Acts. The Bill proposes three additional amendments to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act which were the subject of specific referendum recommendations in the Joint Select Committee report. That report, however, was almost exclusively concerned with reviewing the Electoral Act rather than the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act.

Whilst I said that we were not happy with some of the components of this legislation and will be moving amendments to that effect shortly, I just want to take a few moments to point out those features of the Bill that we find acceptable. We are reasonably happy with the following points: the first is that the existing provisions for Commonwealth money to be spent on the preparation and distribution of written arguments be extended to have that material prepared in forms suitable for the visually impaired, a most commonsense approach and one that we support. The second point we support is the removal of the obligation on broadcasters and publishers to furnish returns for a referendum where it is held in conjunction with an election. The third point we support is the making of overseas polling officials subject to the same penalties for neglect of duty as officials in Australia. Once again, that is a commonsense approach. The fourth point we support is the extension from 10 to 13 days of the period for the return of all postal votes sent by electors directly to district returning officers. The fifth point we support is the repeal of the requirement that printers furnish returns of referendum printing.

The sixth point we agree with is the requirement of Commonwealth and State governments to comply with the Act to the same extent as other participants in the electoral processes; that is, the bind the Crown provision. The last point that I wish to make known tonight is that the Opposition agrees with the removal of the existing time limits on the Governor-General's ability to alter the referendum polling day and/or return of the writs if the referendum is held on other than an election day. Those are the points that we agree with. So, it is quite plain that we do not disagree with the entire legislation. But there are areas of concern, and I want to state those to the House tonight.
The first area of concern relates to clause 8 (b). This clause defines the means by which a voter's intention is ascertained. Basically it says:
. . . regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

The Opposition believes that this will only add to the confusion in determining a valid vote rather than, as it attempts to do, clarify it. If honourable members refer to the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984 and look specifically at section 24, they will find that this matter is easily classified in points (a) and (b), which state:
The voting at a referendum shall be by ballot and each elector shall indicate his vote-
(a) if he approves the proposed law-by writing the word ``Yes'' in the space provided on the ballot-paper; or
(b) if he does not approve the proposed law-by writing the word ``No'' in the space so provided.

On reading that section of the Act it is quite clear, it does not confuse one; and the Opposition believes that to try to define it any further will actually defeat the purpose and will create more confusion and cause more problems. So, for that reason we are concerned about this issue.

Going back to the Government's amendment which is designed to clarify, it is possible to find different interpretations of clause 8. There is always difficulty in exactly defining how to determine a voter's intention. If we look at recommendation 99 on pages 143 to 145 of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform report No. 2, we will see some of the debate that took place and advice that was given in forming the Committee's final recommendation. But from our point of view this amendment proposed by the Government is superfluous and will only add to the confusion of whose job it is to determine these things. If section 24 in the original Act is adhered to, it is painfully obvious that it will actually clarify the matter quite easily and distinctly and leave minimum room for confusion. So, we ask the Government to consider this point, because we believe that adding this amendment that it proposes will actually add more confusion to the issue.

Our next concern relates to clause 10 of the Bill. This clause enables the Australian Electoral Commission to extend, by 48 hours, the time in which acts must be completed in the event of a failure by any person to perform a statutory duty or function. The 48-hour extension proposal first emerged before the 1984 election, when potential and actual industrial action was threatened and that threatened the ability of the Electoral Commission to meet its statutory obligations under the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the allotted time. The Electoral Act contained provisions that could have been invoked against officers of the Electoral Commission involved in industrial action, including a mandatory injunction directing an officer to perform the duties required of him under that Act. The Commission considered that these remedies were not adequate; and it did not consider that an increase in existing penalties would be a suitable solution. The Joint Select Committee therefore recommended the 48-hour extension rule, and this was incorporated into the Electoral Act last year.

However, it is the Opposition's view that this proposal is bad in principle, because it is a virtual acquiescence in the acceptance of industrial muscle and industrial action. We believe that no government should fall prey to this type of activity. We note also that, in the course of trying to justify this extension of 48 hours, the Government has included things like acts of God and goodness knows what else. But there is no doubt at all from our reading of the situation that this inclusion in the Act is designed purely and simply to acquiesce in the use of industrial muscle, and that is something that no government can afford to bend to.

Our last concern relates to the requirement that a voter must have lived within the division within which he or she is voting for at least some time during the three months prior to the polling date. This of course brings the Electoral Act as it applies to referendums into line with the Act as it applies to general elections. This Act relating to general elections was passed through the Parliament during May and June last year and was subjected at the time to considerable debate, with the Liberal Party and the National Party taking opposing views on the matter. The Nationals voted against its inclusion. However, this was not the majority view on the day. Since then, following the 11 July 1987 election, considerable concern has been expressed by a wide range of people in the community, in the media and throughout the country. This concern should cause alarm in our community, because there is apparent in this part of the Act a gaping hole that threatens to weaken or even destroy the integrity of our electoral system, thus causing people to lose confidence in the results of an election in the future.

Why is this so? Because it is now possible for a political party in a marginal seat to move on paper a couple of hundred of its supporters to that particular electorate, thus possibly changing the outcome of an election in such a marginal seat. This can be achieved by using the very lenient residential requirements which are now in the Act and which the Government wishes to install in this Bill relating to referendums. It is possible under these relaxed rules for itinerants to enrol wherever they like, with the requirement that a residential address be given but that a post office box number may be used as the point of contact. How does the Electoral Commissioner get in touch with a person to confirm that he still lives in the division? He can do this only by writing a letter to the post office box.

This is not a sufficient guarantee. It does leave open the opportunity of abuse of the system and, of course, this opportunity, as I have mentioned before, has been the subject of quite a wide ranging debate in the community, which has expressed concern. I believe that it deserves further consideration by the Minister and the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many new enrolee letters do you get back marked `address unknown'?

—The honourable member for Farrer raises a particularly pertinent question. I have heard in debate around the countryside that these examples are evidence of the fact that there could be gaping holes in our legislation, which were not intended in its original drafting but which could be apparent now and which do deserve consideration. So, with hindsight the Liberal and National parties agree that it is vital to review this aspect of the Act to ascertain exactly what deficiencies there are in it. In fact, it is most important that the Government take note of our concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: To delay this aspect of the legislation is eminently reasonable, particularly in light of the fact that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform will be reviewing this very matter in a few weeks time. So, why does the Government not wait until after the Committee has considered this matter and made its recommendations? If the Government does not follow this up by waiting for the Select Committee to report, I believe that it will leave in place one of the most dangerous aspects of the Electoral Act which could threaten the very future integrity of our electoral processes.

I state once again that the Opposition sees merit in some aspects of the legislation. However, we are genuinely concerned by those three matters we have raised and we do hope that the Minister will give them due consideration. I ask him to do this for the sake of an electoral system that has served us well, that has never had its integrity questioned, that has the confidence of the people and that forms one of the most basic platforms of our democratic system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Amendment Bill 1988. In doing so I wish to commend the people involved, especially the members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, who worked hard to put forward proposals on this matter. Those proposals are the ones which are incorporated in the Bill. Referendums are extremely important in a democracy because they allow us to shape the Constitution and to change it when circumstances warrant such change. Australia has a pretty poor record in its capacity to change the Constitution even when changes are warranted.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen this in constitutional conventions and commissions which have been bipartisan and have accepted a number of changes, but when those changes have been put to the people in a referendum unfortunately it was not possible to get a majority position. That is partly because the rules for changing the Constitution are very tough-probably amongst the toughest of any constitution in the world. Not only do we need a majority of the voters of the nation-what would be considered a democratic majority in most countries-but also we need a majority of the States, which is a very difficult proposition to achieve. That goes back to the concern of the fathers of the Federation to ensure that the Constitution could not be changed in favour of the major States as they existed then.

Perhaps it is time to rethink this provision in the Constitution in view of the fact that we are now a much more mature nation. We think of ourselves more as a nation. Perhaps the view of the majority of the people should be sufficient to change the Constitution rather than having the problem of also getting the majority of the States in favour of a change. It is possible to misuse that provision in such a way that the smaller States could theoretically completely frustrate the performance of the larger States in what might be essential constitutional changes.

We are concerned in this Bill to ensure the machinery for the changing of the Constitution in the sense of people's understanding and comprehension of what is going on in a referendum, to ensure that that process is satisfied, to ensure that we maximise that process. That is an important matter because it has often been argued that a kind of emotion overtakes people in Australia when it comes to referendums. That emotion is, I suppose, summed up in two letters-NO. When people vote in referendums in Australia most of the time they vote no, even when there has been bipartisan agreement on some of the proposals put forward. Obviously one of the reasons for that has been the failure of people to comprehend sufficiently what is at stake in the referendum proposal. In order to overcome that problem we are inserting provisions in the legislation which require the case for the yes vote and the case for the no vote to be put to the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —In simple language.

—Yes, in simple language. The provisions as they stand require the case to be put only in pamphlets, in written form. There is no provision for the case to be put in verbal form, to be communicated to people who cannot read or who may be visually impaired. With these provisions we are allowing for an audible form of the yes and no case to be put. That proposed new provision is relevant not only to people who are visually impaired but also to people whose reading capacity unfortunately is not very good. Let us face it, those people who know something about what is happening in education know that there are a considerable number of people whose reading capacity is poor and who therefore would not be able to read the various yes and no cases that are presented. It is important that they be able to comprehend those cases by having them verbally presented in the way the provisions allow. That is a very important provision and it ought to be supported. I think the Opposition supports it.

SPEECH.PARA: I was surprised, however, to hear that the Opposition is going to oppose certain provisions, even though some of them were members of the Select Committee and even though they appeared to support the general thrust in the Select Committee. I was mystified to find that they will oppose the provision which relates to the question of the yes or no vote, which seeks to make it clear what the intention of the voter is. In situations where we have problems with referendums, where we want to improve the ability of people actually to express their opinions in a democracy, what is wrong with making it absolutely clear whether it is a yes or no vote? There is nothing wrong with that, yet the Opposition seems to think that there is some sinister conspiracy behind this view.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is.

—What is it? We certainly did not get anything out of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp), about what this conspiracy was supposed to be. Proposed new subsection 93 (9) states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purpose of ascertaining a voter's intention, regard shall only be had to the word `Yes' or `No' written alone or without words of qualification.

What is wrong with that? That is just to clarify the position. Any confusion that may arise in the mind of an electoral officer, for example, in relation to the intention of the voter with respect to the constitutional amendments and other referendums would be clarified. I do not see why the Opposition thinks that there is something sinister about it. The Opposition claims that the present Act allows for that situation, but the point is that, as honourable members will see if they read the report of the Select Committee, there has been some ambiguous interpretation of these matters and this provision will make it absolutely clear. I do not see that the Opposition's argument has any validity.

There was also some complaint from the Opposition about the relaxed rules in relation to the residence requirements and the period people had lived in an electorate when voting in a referendum. The argument presented by the Opposition spokesman was based on the view that somehow people could move from one electorate to the other and that this was a problem in the electoral process. it might be a problem in the electoral process-I do not know whether it is-but it is certainly not a problem with referendums. It is an absurdity to argue that we are going to move thousands of people from one State to another in order to get a referendum result. It has no impact at all on a referendum if people move from one electorate to another because the counting is on the basis of the whole nation in the one instance and the whole State in another instance.

The argument presented about what might be happening with people changing from one electorate to another may have some relevance to general elections and maybe it needs looking at, but this Bill does not deal with that issue. This Bill deals with the referendum question and it is not relevant whether a person is in the electorate of Calwell or Burke. Whichever electorate a person is in, his referendum vote counts as one. This argument raises problems where none exist, in my view. If there is some concern about previous rules and laws in relation to the electoral system for voting in general elections that matter ought to go back to the Select Committee for consideration. If they make some recommendations which ought to be adopted, those recommendations can be dealt with at the appropriate time. We reject the arguments being presented by the Opposition in this matter. I go back to the importance of our ensuring that referendum proposals are dealt with in the most democratic fashion, that people know what they are doing when they are dealing with such proposals and that we do not have any problems in relation to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all representatives in this House and we all represent people. We will have our political dogfights over certain issues but mainly we deal with the day to day problems of our electorates. If we do not, we do not get elected and we are not worth our salt. People come to see us about various problems-lack of housing, matrimonial breakups-where we have to help families. SPEECH.PARA: It absolutely sickens me sometimes that we have these single issue politicians who march around and get involved in one single issue without thinking about why they are elected. They are all over Australia but there is a predominance of them in Tasmania. They are only interested in one single issue. I repeat, we are representatives and we look after every group of people we can. People come to see us and we do our best.

It happens that a fellow I knew years ago came to see me. He is a normal, decent Australian with five children and he came to see me about a problem affecting his family-spina bifida. When one has a family one is sometimes unaware of the sicknesses and illnesses other people are afflicted with. This chap told me a story about one of his daughters and he wrote me a letter. I thought I would read the letter tonight. It might co-opt support from both sides of the House and it might acquaint some honourable members with the problems of having a family and having one child afflicted by spina bifida. The letter commences, `Dear Bruce'-that is my name, Bruce Goodluck, if anyone does not know me-and goes on to read:
I have left with you a copy of the submission which was forwarded to the Federal Minister for Health in April 1987.
Incidentally, I am not being political about this. The letter continues:
It was submitted with the feeling that the Federal Government would recognise the concern that ASBA has for its 2000+ Spina Bifida sufferers throughout Australia.

Spina Bifida incidence in Australia is one in a thousand live births and is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors, although extensive research has not yet determined the real cause.
The effects of Spina Bifida to a child are:

1. Paralysis and Loss of Sensation-as the spinal cord becomes defective the nerves therein are damaged. The result of this is that the messages from the brain to the muscles (causing movement) and the body to the brain are impaired.

2. Lack of Bladder and Bowel Control (Incontinence)-The nerves which control the bladder and bowel are located in the lower region of the spinal cord. This having been damaged in a Spina Bifida person causes incontinence.

3. Hydrocephalus-in about 80%-90% of Spina Bifida births an associated abnormality known as Hydrocephalus occurs. This is a build up of spinal fluid in the head arising from a blockage of the natural drainage of this fluid caused by the defective spinal cord.
Spina Bifida strikes right across the community; the rich, the poor, single mothers and the unemployed. The birth of a Spina Bifida child to any family is devastating.

The joy of the impending birth of a new baby is something which most families hold dearly. To the 2000+ families throughout Australia who have had their expectations shattered by the birth of a handicapped child, it is quite something else, I can assure you.

Within 24 hours the baby will have its first operation, and from that day on the visits in and out of hospitals become neverending. The child will have shunt blockages, orthopaedic problems, physiotherapy and the continuing infection to kidneys-because of the lack of bladder control.

Costs in the raising of `normal' children are to the average Australian earning the average wage, at the least very high-the cost of raising a handicapped child to an average family becomes a large burden.
When we talk of cost we must also look at effects on other family members, ie time/money spent on the handicapped child . . .

This man is just an ordinary everyday family man with problems with which I and others would be completely unaware. We may be aware but if it does not happen to us we probably do not get involved. The letter continues:

. . . to the detriment of other children/family members. The cost of social impact-how much time are the parents restricted to staying in their own environment restricting other family members in their movements.

ASBA believes the parents and the Spina Bifida child have a right to lead as normal a life as is humanly possible and that all resources and appliances required for Spina Bifidas to achieve their ultimate should be available at little or no cost.

To this aim, we are requesting that you, in association with any of your parliamentary colleagues and any other person in your opinion would assist in persuading the Federal Government that the wrong decision was made originally, take up our case to have all incontinence aids made available through Government Schemes.

When one compares those two polls it is interesting to see the swings anticipated and how people can extrapolate from previous election results the swings necessary to change government in New South Wales. I say it is interesting because if one takes the seats in the Illawarra and surrounding areas one sees that there is an incredible difference between what Mackerras and Chaples have to say is required to change government. Let us run quickly through some of the seats.

The first is the seat of Kiera, a newly created seat located in the main within my electorate. Under Chaples predictions a 9.1 per cent swing is necessary to change that seat from the projected Labor Party to the Liberal Party. Mackerras, on the other hand, says it is 15 per cent plus. In the seat of Wollongong they are both about the same-a 0.2 per cent or 0.1 per cent swing to change hands. In the seat of Burragorang Chaples says about 11 per cent and Mackerras says somewhere between 12 per cent and 15 per cent. It is hard to extrapolate on this particular graph. In the seat of Illawarra, once again they are fairly close together, somewhere in the order of 14 per cent, 16 per cent, 18 per cent or even 20 per cent. In Kiama, Chaples says 13 per cent while Mackerras says it is somewhere slightly above 10 per cent. In Camden, Chaples says a swing of less than 2 per cent is required to change hands while Mackerras says 7.3 per cent. In Minchinbury, Chaples says the swing needed is 9.8 per cent and Mackerras says somewhere over 10 per cent. In Heathcote, Chaples says less than one per cent is necessary for it to change hands to the Liberals while Mackerras says 4.3 per cent.
