There is no question that this particular move, which will come into effect on 31 March, will be detrimental to people living in country and regional areas throughout Australia. The closure of agencies will not be restricted to any one State; it will affect all country and regional areas throughout Australia. I question the Government's motives as to why it has introduced this particular measure. The reason stated by the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) when the legislation closing Medicare agencies was introduced, was that it was intended that the Government would save taxpayers' money by implementing this measure.

—I correct my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland. The Minister may have referred to $1.2m but the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia Ltd, the private medical insurers, decided that it did not agree with the Minister's figures. The Association engaged the well respected private consultant, the Touche Ross organisation, to conduct a far-reaching investigation into the cost savings associated with this measure. Touche Ross, in its report, pointed out clearly that rather than the savings claimed by the Minister being effected by this measure, the savings would in fact be negligible and in some cases the measure would cost the taxpayers more than the present Medicare agency arrangements. To confirm that claim by Touche Ross I refer to Cessnock where the Health Insurance Commission itself has admitted that it will have to pay $85,000 a year to run a Medicare agency to provide the services which cost taxpayers less than $42,000 a year under the previous agency arrangements. SPEECH.PARA: In addition to causing inconvenience to people living in country and regional areas, this proposal will be damaging also to people working in private health insurance firms that are at this stage able to provide agency arrangements. I was contacted by St Luke's Health Insurance in Launceston and I was advised that it could cost in the order of 35 jobs for those who currently work in that organisation in a regional centre such as Launceston. These facts will be apparent when this measure is introduced by the Government on 31 March.

In addition to these matters I point out to my friends on the other side of the House that a number of people associated with Australian Labor Party organisations around Australia equally cannot understand why the Government should introduce this measure. They commenced their letter to the Minister for Community Services and Health by saying:

We write to you in the strongest possible terms, seeking a reversal of the decision announced in the 1987 Budget papers to close the Medicare Agency operated by the Associated Pulp and Paper Makers' Council.
That will give honourable members some idea of the strength of feeling of these people about this measure being taken by the Government. The closing paragraph is equally as interesting. It reads:
Given that the cost saving is at best negligible, we in the labour movement would not expect a Labor Government to proceed with such a proposal.

That is the feeling from labour organisations. The grass roots of Labor's constituency is not satisfied with the action to close Medicare agencies. The action will not save money for the Government. It will cost jobs in country and regional areas. It will not provide the services that people living in regional areas want. I strongly urge the Government to review its decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use this opportunity to bring honourable members' attention to the continuing abuses of human rights taking place in Malaysia. SPEECH.PARA: On 28 October 1987, the Government of Dr Mahathir swooped on its opponents, rounding up and gaoling 90 persons under section 73 of the Internal Security Act. Those arrested were Government critics, social activists and conservationists who were involved in exposing poverty, governmental corruption and environmental vandalism. Honourable members may also be aware that the Malaysian Government has closed down three opposition newspapers-the Star, Sin Chew Jit Poh and Watan. Honourable members may also know that Dr Mahathir has recently survived a close-fought leadership battle within his own Party which he won only narrowly.

One hundred and six people have been detained since 28 October last year. The first point I make is that it has no effect at all on Queensland, no affect at all on South Australia, and a marginal effect on Western Australia. So it is related to the three States I want to talk about-Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Those agency agreements were made in 1984 on the introduction of Medicare in order to provide a measure of relief from the impact of the introduction of Medicare so that the small regional funds would have time to restructure and adapt to the new Medicare system. They were always seen as likely to be a temporary measure to cover that transition period, and of course in the time since Medicare was introduced all of those funds have been freed up to take on other insurance activities so that they are no longer restricted just to health insurance. Provided they have developed those other activities, they should safely be able to cope with the Government's decision.

The honourable member for Lyons alleged that this measure would not save any money. If he looks at the Budget Papers he will see that the money is saved. The Health Insurance Commission will have its administrative costs reduced by $1.5m next year as a result of not having to pay these agencies. That is a clear saving to Government. I think it is about time the Liberal Opposition recognised that we face these tough rationalising decisions. Is it better to provide a massive spread of Medicare offices giving the administrative service, or reduce the number of Medicare offices somewhat, provided people are still looked after, in order to have more nurses, more hospital beds and more nursing homes? My decision will always be, when faced with issues like that, that we can make some savings on the administrative side at marginal inconvenience to some people and in turn be able to put more money into services. So this $1.5m saving is a real saving, a saving which can be used to provide these services.

Again let me point out the rather wasteful nature of these agency arrangements. We are not faced just with the cost of paying for the agency; every transaction dealt with by the agency has to be dealt with again in the Medicare office itself and entered into the computer system. So we have a very wasteful, repetitious system, and the honourable member for Lyons when doing his financial calculations left out altogether the need to get these transactions from the agencies and put them into the Medicare system, which really means dealing twice with every transaction. So that is another major source of saving.

Finally, in a number of these places the agencies will be replaced by full Medicare offices, which of course can do more than the agencies. They can provide the total range of Medicare services. In Tasmania, for instance, which already has more Medicare offices per head of population than any other part of Australia, the only area which might be significantly affected is the west coast. We decided to put in a new full Medicare office in Queenstown and there is to be a reduction of one agency in Wesley Vale, but there is a good Medicare service very close to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened in Launceston?

—There are already Medicare offices in Launceston, so the closing down of that one agency will not have any real impact on people able to get their services in Launceston. In the other areas in Victoria and New South Wales we tackled the problem in the same way. We replaced a number of agencies with full offices so that there was a proper spread of offices across the country. I think anyone who looks at this kind of decision will say it was right to make these administrative savings in order to have money to provide real services on the ground.
